LEVY.deftext:
to impose, collect; to carry on (war) 
To LEVY is to impose something like a tax or a fine, and to collect it by authority or force. 
"The king LEVIED a new tax on the citizens." 
"The judge LEVIED a huge fine on the company." 
LEVY is also used in a different sense, to mean "to start or make war." 
"The king decided to LEVY war against his enemies." 
As a noun, a LEVY is the act of imposing or the thing imposed, a _tax_. 
"The governor announced a new LEVY on cigarettes."

ONSLAUGHT.deftext:
an attack, assault 
ONSLAUGHT is related to the word _slaughter_. An ONSLAUGHT is a furious attack, of an enemy or of something like an enemy. 
"The enemy launched a fierce ONSLAUGHT against our army." 
"The ONSLAUGHT of the illness put him in the hospital for a week." 
"They built a wall to protect themselves from the ONSLAUGHT of the cold wind."

THWART.deftext:
to block, prevent, foil, frustrate 
To THWART someone is to block or prevent him from doing something. THWART suggests making things difficult for a person by running counter to what he wants or plans. 
"The governor successfully THWARTED his opponent's attempt to win the election." 
"Her plans to attend the party were THWARTED by a sudden illness." 
"The baby screams whenever he is THWARTED"--that is, whenever he is not allowed to do something he wants to do. 
In the Pretest, many people select _delay_ as the meaning of THWART, but THWART suggests more complete and successful interference. 
"Lack of funds _delayed_ the project, but the principal's opposition finally THWARTED it."

DEGENERATE.deftext:
to worsen, decline, deteriorate 
To DEGENERATE is to become worse, to pass from a higher state to a lower or worse one. See _de-_ under Prefixes. The word can be used about physical, mental, or moral qualities. 
"The disease caused his health to DEGENERATE and now he's confined to bed." 
"The play started brilliantly, but then DEGENERATED into a typical silly comedy." 
"The once great lawyer has DEGENERATED into a drunken bum." 
DEGENERATE is also an adjective and a noun, pronounced (di-jen'-:i—rit). These words are most often used about lowered moral qualities. 
"He may once have been a good man, but now he is just a DEGENERATE." 
"The DEGENERATE emperor practiced every sort of vice."

ELITE.deftext:
the chosen ones, a superior or highly special group 
Note the pronunciation. ELITE originally came from a Latin word meaning to _choose_. The ELITE are the chosen ones, a group of people who are considered superior because of their achievements, wealth, power, or other quality. 
"This store would only do business with the social ELITE." 
"His tremendous feats as a hitter put him among baseball's ELITE." 
"He was part of the political ELITE who ran the country year after year." 
ELITE is also used as an adjective, meaning _choice_ or _best_. 
"An ELITE group of soldiers was selected to lead the attack." 
Other forms of the word: ELITISM, n. ELITIST, adj., n.

INDIFFERENT.deftext:
uninterested, unconcerned, unimpressive, commonplace 
The most common meaning of INDIFFERENT is "not caring one way or the other"; in this sense the word is usually followed by _to_. 
"I love swimming, but I am INDIFFERENT to winter sports." 
"How can you be so INDIFFERENT to the suffering of these people?" 
Another meaning of INDIFFERENT is "neither good nor bad," _commonplace_, _mediocre_. 
"It was an INDIFFERENT novel; I've read much better." 
"He played the piano very well, but he sang INDIFFERENTLY." 
Other forms of the word: INDIFFERENCE, n.

KALEIDOSCOPIC.deftext:
continually changing, extremely varied 
A KALEIDOSCOPE is a tube that contains mirrors and pieces of colored glass. When the tube is turned, the glass appears in an endless variety of multicolored patterns. The adjective KALEIDOSCOPIC means "formed by or relating to a KALEIDOSCOPE." See _-ic_ under Suffixes. The word is usually used in a general sense, about shapes or events that are constantly shifting into new patterns, as if seen through a KALEIDOSCOPE. 
"The reporters could barely keep up with the KALEIDOSCOPIC events of the day." 
"It was a time of KALEIDOSCOPIC change, when no one knew what to expect next." 
Other forms of the word: KALEIDOSCOPE, n.

PATERNAL.deftext:
having to do with a father, fatherly 
PATERNAL comes from _pater_, the Latin word for _father_, and means "like or of a father." See _-al_ under Suffixes. 
"He took a PATERNAL interest in the boy. He treated him as if he were his own son." 
"I didn't like his PATERNAL attitude. He talked to me like a father talking to his little girl." 
Similar words are _maternal_, meaning _motherly_, and _fraternal_, meaning _brotherly_.

RETROSPECT.deftext:
a review 
RETROSPECT comes from a Latin word meaning to _look back at_. The _spect_ part is also found in other words having to do with seeing, like _inspect_ and _spectacles_. A RETROSPECT is a view of past events. The word is usually used in the phrase "in RETROSPECT," which means _in review_, _in looking back_. 
"In RETROSPECT, I guess I made a mistake in doing what I did." 
"At the time we thought we had failed, but in RETROSPECT it seems that we did pretty well." 
Other forms of the word: RETROSPECTION, n. RETROSPECTIVE, adj., n.

TORRENT.deftext:
a flood, deluge 
A TORRENT is a rush or surge of water or other liquid. The word stresses the rapidity and violence of the water. 
"Their rowboat was swept away in the TORRENT." 
"A TORRENT of lava flooded the city at the foot of the volcano." 
TORRENT is also used about any kind of sudden surge. 
"The quarterback was greeted with a TORRENT of abuse from the crowd."

ZENITH.deftext:
a peak, summit, highest point 
In astronomy, the ZENITH is the point in the sky that is directly overhead. ZENITH has come to mean the peak or highest point of anything. 
"The singer's popularity reached its ZENITH just after World War II." 
"He was at the ZENITH of his powers when he was tragically killed in an auto accident." 
"The country's prosperity was at its ZENITH for only a short time before the depression started."

BIGOTED.deftext:
intolerant, narrow-minded 
A BIGOT is a person who is completely intolerant of any belief, opinion, or religion that differs from his own. 
"He is such a BIGOT that he won't even speak to someone who doesn't belong to the same party as he does." 
BIGOTED is the adjective from BIGOT. 
"He complained that the company executives were BIGOTED and would hire only people of their own religion." 
"They didn't want to appear BIGOTED, so they invited people of different races, creeds, and political parties to the conference." 
The most common mistakes for BIGOTED in the Pretest are _vicious_ and _greedy_. People who make those mistakes perhaps know that it is bad to be BIGOTED, but don't know exactly why. 
Other forms of the word: BIGOT, n. BIGOTRY, n.

EXCEPTIONAL.deftext:
unusual, rare, uncommon 
An EXCEPTION is something that doesn't follow the rule. 
"All the students passed the test with one EXCEPTION--Tommy Jones." 
EXCEPTIONAL is the adjective from EXCEPTION. See _-al_ under Suffixes. Something that is EXCEPTIONAL is out of the ordinary, doesn't follow the rule. 
"There have been an EXCEPTIONAL number of warm days this spring." 
The word is usually used in a positive sense, about something that is better than average or uncommonly good. 
"He thought it was an EXCEPTIONAL movie--one of the best he'd seen." 
Most people who make a mistake on this word choose _perfect_ as the synonym. Something that is EXCEPTIONAL may be unusually good, but it is not necessarily _perfect_. 
Other forms of the word: EXCEPT, v., prep. EXCEPTION, n.

IMPERATIVE.deftext:
urgent, essential, obligatory, pressing 
IMPERATIVE is related to the words _emperor_ and _imperial_. All come from a Latin word meaning to _command_. Something that is IMPERATIVE is like a command; it is not to be disobeyed or avoided. 
"She said it was IMPERATIVE that we treat the most badly injured soldiers first." 
"It is IMPERATIVE that we leave this building before it collapses." 
In grammar, an IMPERATIVE sentence is one that expresses a command. 
"Stop that right now!" is an IMPERATIVE sentence.

PERCEIVE.deftext:
to notice, observe, become aware of, sense 
To PERCEIVE something is to become aware of it, especially through the senses. 
"We PERCEIVED a faint light in the distance." 
"He could PERCEIVE very small differences in sounds." 
"The critics failed to PERCEIVE the greatness of the novel until many years later." 
_Trick_ is often chosen as the meaning of PERCEIVE. This is probably due to a confusion of PERCEIVE with _deceive_, which means to _trick_. 
Other forms of the word: PERCEPTIBLE, adj. PERCEPTION, n. PERCEPTIVE, adj.

questions.prompt: Do you assist someone by THWARTING him?
Would a DEGENERATE make a pleasant neighbor?
Do most people belong to the social ELITE?
Do people get excited about INDIFFERENT movies?
Would your PATERNAL grandfather be your father's father?
When a person talks about something in RETROSPECT, is he talking about the future?
Can someone speak with a TORRENT of words?
If someone's reputation is at its ZENITH, is it as high as it will ever get?
Does a BIGOT believe that everyone should be treated equally?
Would it be EXCEPTIONAL for someone to run a mile in less than three minutes?
Is "Are you coming?" an IMPERATIVE sentence?
Can you PERCEIVE something with your eyes?
Congress passed an additional LEVY on imported oil.
The ONSLAUGHT of the blizzard caught them completely unprepared.
Every time she tried to go to the beach something happened to THWART her plans.
The new power plant DEGENERATES a great deal of electricity.
Several ELITE musicians were chosen to play at the White House.
The judge was INDIFFERENT to the criminal's cries for mercy.
The result was completely KALEIDOSCOPIC. All our work was ruined.
Her PATERNAL instincts were aroused whenever she saw a newborn baby.
In RETROSPECT we realized we should have paid more attention to our parents.
The lake was so calm and peaceful it looked like a TORRENT.
Fads quickly reach the ZENITH of their popularity, and then they fade away just as quickly.
His BIGOTED attitude makes it difficult for him to accept others on their individual merits.
The fourth pair of skis was EXCEPTIONAL, since only three of us were going skiing.
The teacher felt it was IMPERATIVE that her students be able to read well.
Too late he PERCEIVED that she had been right from the start.

IMPAIR.deftext:
make worse, weaken, injure 
To IMPAIR something is to make it worse, to do harm to it. The word often suggests damage that gradually increases. 
"Smoking cigarettes will damage your lungs and IMPAIR your breathing." 
"His eyesight was IMPAIRED by reading in very dim light." 
"The scandal will IMPAIR their chances of winning the election." 
In the Pretest, many people choose _destroy_ as the meaning of IMPAIR. When you IMPAIR something, you cause it some damage, but you do not _destroy_ it.

SYNOPSIS.deftext:
a summary, outline 
A SYNOPSIS is a short summary or outline, usually of the plot of a book, play, or movie. 
"It was difficult to make an understandable SYNOPSIS of a book with so many characters doing so many different things." 
"According to the SYNOPSIS, the next act takes place in the living room." 
"The announcer gave a SYNOPSIS of the president's speech and summarized the main ideas." 
"We hurriedly read through several SYNOPSES to prepare for the test." 
Usage: The plural form of SYNOPSIS is SYNOPSES.

BLISS.deftext:
joy, happiness, delight 
BLISS is a state of complete happiness or great joy. It is a very strong word, and often refers to the joys of heaven. 
"She was unhappy in life, but hoped for eternal BLISS after death." 
"When he fell in love, he realized he had never known such BLISS before." 
"Their years of perfect BLISS were ended when he became ill." 
BLISSFUL is the adjective from BLISS and means "full of or causing great happiness." "BLISSFUL ignorance" is happiness resulting from a lack of knowledge of events or circumstances that could cause unhappiness. 
"They lived in BLISSFUL ignorance of the great dangers that surrounded them." 
Other forms of the word: BLISSFUL, adj.

INFRINGE.deftext:
to break, violate; to encroach, trespass 
To INFRINGE a rule, law, or agreement is to break it, to fail to obey it. 
"He accused us of INFRINGING the contract we had signed with him." 
"They INFRINGED the treaty by sending troops into the other country." 
INFRINGE is often used with _on_ or _upon_ to mean "to break in upon," to _encroach_. 
"We must never INFRINGE upon the rights of others." The noun form of INFRINGE is INFRINGEMENT, the act of violating or trespassing. 
"He was accused of copyright infringement because he printed the photo in his book without getting the photographer's authorization." 
Other forms of the word: INFRINGEMENT, n.

MICROBE.deftext:
a bacterium, germ 
The prefix _micro-_ means _very small_. It is used in the word _microscope_, which is an instrument that helps you to see very small objects. A MICROBE is a very small living creature, one that is invisible to the naked eye. The word is used especially about small living things that cause diseases. 
"There are thousands of tiny MICROBES in the air we breathe." 
"The scientists tried to discover the MICROBE that was responsible for the mysterious deaths of the animals." 
The most commonly chosen incorrect answer is _atom_. An _atom_, of course, is a very small thing--in fact, far smaller than a MICROBE. The key difference is that a MICROBE is _alive_ while an atom isn't.

NONENTITY.deftext:
an unimportant person or thing 
An ENTITY is something that exists. The basic meaning of NONENTITY is "something that does not really exist." See _non-_ under Prefixes. Usually, though, NONENTITY is used about a person who is so undistinguished and insignificant that it is as if he didn't exist. 
"Although he came from a famous family, he himself was a NONENTITY." 
"Everyone thought he was a complete NONENTITY, but then it turned out he was a prince in disguise."

TREMULOUS.deftext:
quivering, trembling; timid, fearful 
TREMULOUS is related to the word _tremble_. Someone or something that is TREMULOUS trembles or shakes. 
"The old lady could not hold the cup of tea in her TREMULOUS hands." 
When used about a person, TREMULOUS sometimes suggests that the trembling is due to fear or nervousness. 
"The boy TREMULOUSLY asked the girl if she would dance with him." 
Many people pick _huge_ as the meaning of TREMULOUS. They are probably confusing TREMULOUS with _tremendous_, which sounds and looks very much like it.

VOID.deftext:
emptiness, vacancy 
A VOID is an empty, unfilled space. 
"He gazed into the limitless VOID of outer space." 
"There is an aching VOID in my heart since you left me." 
"The car plunged over the cliff and into the VOID." 
VOID is also an adjective, meaning _empty_, _vacant_. The word is usually found in the legal term, "null and VOID," which means "having no legal force." 
"The judge declared that the contract was null and VOID." VOID is also used in this sense as a verb, meaning to _nullify_. 
"The judge VOIDED the contract."

ASSAIL.deftext:
to attack, assault 
To ASSAIL someone is to attack him, usually suddenly or repeatedly. 
"The mob ASSAILED the soldiers with rocks and sticks." 
"He was ASSAILED by blows on the head as he tried to escape from the crowd." 
ASSAIL can be used in a general sense about any kind of attack. 
"As soon as he started the project he was ASSAILED by doubts about whether it would be successful." 
An ASSAILANT is someone who attacks. 
"Dick was beaten up in the alley by several unknown ASSAILANTS." 
Other forms of the word: ASSAILANT, n.

HYPOCRISY.deftext:
insincerity, deceit 
HYPOCRISY comes from a Greek word meaning _acting_. Someone who practices HYPOCRISY acts good or virtuous when in reality he isn't. 
"I can't believe his HYPOCRISY. He always talks about how wrong it is to lie, and he's the worst liar I know." 
"The reporter exposed the HYPOCRISY of the religious leader who in private was a cruel and evil man." 
A HYPOCRITE is someone who pretends to be virtuous when he isn't. 
"They're all HYPOCRITES who don't practice what they preach." 
_Vanity_ is a popular choice as the meaning of HYPOCRISY. Both _vanity_ and HYPOCRISY are vices, but a person can have one fault without the other. 
Other forms of the word: HYPOCRITE, n. HYPOCRITICAL, adj.

DESTITUTE.deftext:
extremely poor, needy; lacking, deprived 
Someone who is DESTITUTE is absolutely penniless and lacks the basic necessities of life, such as food, clothing, and shelter. 
"They had always been poor, but the fire left them homeless and completely DESTITUTE." 
"I have never been DESTITUTE, but I know what it's like to go hungry." 
"When Mr. Jones died, his widow was left DESTITUTE." 
The phrase DESTITUTE _of_ means _lacking_, _not having_, _devoid_. 
"We could tell the tree was dying because it was completely DESTITUTE of leaves in the middle of the summer." 
"The cruel dictator was DESTITUTE of ordinary human feelings."

ENDOW.deftext:
to provide, give 
ENDOW means to _give_ or _provide_ something for the benefit of a person or an institution. 
"The grateful parent ENDOWED a new wing in the hospital in his son's name." 
"The school is looking for someone to ENDOW a new library." 
To be ENDOWED _with_ something is to have it naturally. 
"She is ENDOWED with a great talent for painting." 
"He was ENDOWED with the gift for making money." 
The noun form of ENDOW is ENDOWMENT, which means a _gift_, usually of money or property. 
"Harvard College received an ENDOWMENT of several hundred books." 
Other forms of the word: ENDOWMENT, n.

IMBECILIC.deftext:
idiotic, weak-minded 
An IMBECILE is an extremely weak-minded person, one who cannot develop mentally beyond the age of about seven. IMBECILIC is the adjective from IMBECILE, and means "like an IMBECILE." 
See _-ic_ under Suffixes. 
"His actions were so IMBECILIC that no one could believe he was an adult." 
"She said Bill's ideas were IMBECILIC and not worth discussing." 
Other forms of the word: IMBECILE, n.

LOATH.deftext:
unwilling, reluctant, disinclined 
LOATH means _extremely unwilling_, _reluctant_. 
"He was LOATH to go." 
"They were LOATH to lend us any more money until we had paid back what we already owed." 
"I am LOATH to sign anything I haven't read first." 
Do not confuse LOATH and _loathe_ (pronounced (pronunciation). The verb _loathe_ means to _hate_, to _despise_. 
"I _loathe_ having to get up early." 
LOATH has a similar meaning, but is only used as an adjective. 
"He is LOATH to stay behind. He loathes being left out of anything." 
Usage: LOATH is also sometimes spelled loth.

THRONG.deftext:
a crowd, multitude 
A THRONG is a great number of people crowded together. 
"THRONGS of people came to see the hit movie." 
"The small child got lost in the THRONG at the parade." 
THRONG is also a verb, meaning to _crowd together_ or to _fill by crowding_. 
"People THRONGED into the street for the parade." 
"The park was THRONGED with people waiting to hear the concert."

questions.prompt: Will eating poisoned food IMPAIR your health?
Does the SYNOPSIS of a book include every word?
Would most people like to have somebody INFRINGE upon their rights?
Is it difficult to see a MICROBE?
Would TREMULOUS handwriting be difficult to read?
Can a VOID be very large?
Are pigs ENDOWED with the ability to fly?
Would most people like to be called IMBECILIC?
Are children usually LOATH to eat ice cream?
He IMPAIRED the two of us and decided I was the better.
After reading the SYNOPSIS of the TV show in the newspaper, we decided not to watch it.
Their BLISSFUL marriage lasted over fifty years.
The truce between the countries was INFRINGED when enemy soldiers attacked our town.
The doctor examined the tissue under the microscope to try to spot the MICROBES.
The public relations man said he could take any NONENTITY and make him world famous in six weeks.
In a TREMULOUS voice he said he'd never been so scared in his entire life.
We built the biggest VOID in the city.
Police searched for the ASSAILANT who had attacked the man in broad daylight.
She felt it was HYPOCRISY to say you liked a person if you really didn't.
This program is terrible. The actors on it are completely DESTITUTE of talent.
We are ENDOWED with certain rights under our Constitution.
Everyone praised the play as being truly IMBECILIC.
The boss was LOATH to fire anyone just before Christmas.
THRONGS of people visited the museum for the display of Egyptian treasures.

CAVORT.deftext:
to make merry, prance, jump about 
To CAVORT is to make merry, usually by jumping and dancing about. The word was originally used about a horse and its rider. 
"The mother dog looked on calmly while her puppies CAVORTED in the tall grass." 
"We enjoyed watching the children CAVORTING on the beach." 
"The students CAVORTED on the steps of the school, happy to be going home at last."

CONCEDE.deftext:
to admit, acknowledge; to grant, surrender 
CONCEDE has two different meanings. To CONCEDE something is to admit that it is true. 
"After a long debate Ed finally CONCEDED the point and said we were right." 
"We CONCEDED that we had been a bit hasty in criticizing her." 
The word can also mean to _grant_ or _surrender_. 
"When Jim injured his foot he had to CONCEDE the match to his opponent." 
"As part of the peace treaty they CONCEDED all the territory they had won in the war." 
The most common mistake in the Pretest is to choose _deny_ as the meaning of CONCEDE. This is a confusion of a word with its opposite. People who choose _deny_ as the meaning of CONCEDE perhaps know that CONCEDE has something to do with the truth, but aren't exactly sure what. 
Other forms of the word: CONCESSION, n.

INTEGRAL.deftext:
necessary for completeness, essential 
INTEGRAL is from a Latin word meaning _whole_, _entire_, also the source of the word _integer_. An _integer_, in arithmetic, is a whole number (1, 2, 3, 4 . . .) as opposed to a fraction. Something that is INTEGRAL to something else is necessary for its completeness. 
"This piece is INTEGRAL to the machine. If you remove it, nothing will work." 
INTEGRAL is often found in the phrase "an INTEGRAL part of," which means a _necessary_ or _essential_ part of. 
"Learning vocabulary is an INTEGRAL part of education; without words you can't read."

DOTING.deftext:
: overly fond; weak-minded 
To DOTE on someone is to show excessive affection for him. 
"Our grandmother DOTES on us; she'll give us anything we want." 
DOTING is the adjective from DOTE, and means "showing too much fondness." 
"The DOTING parents couldn't keep their eyes off their new baby." 
"The DOTING husband brought his wife flowers every night." 
In another sense, DOTING is sometimes used to mean _weak-minded_, especially from old age. This sense is particularly found in the noun DOTAGE, which means "feebleness of mind resulting from old age." 
"In his DOTAGE his mind started to wander and it was hard to understand him." 
Other forms of the word: DOTAGE, n. DOTE, v.

INTERIM.deftext:
temporary, provisional 
INTERIM comes directly from a Latin word which means "in the meantime," _meanwhile_. INTERIM is used as a noun in the phrase "in the INTERIM," which means exactly the same as the Latin word. As an adjective, INTERIM means "done or occurring in the meantime," _temporary_. 
"They issued an INTERIM report until the new set of figures came in and they could make it final." 
"They set up an INTERIM government to rule while the new constitution was being written."

LACKLUSTER.deftext:
dull, uninspired 
_Luster_ is _brightness_, the glow of a polished surface. Something which is LACKLUSTER lacks _luster_ or brightness; it is dull, uninspired. The word is especially used about expressions, actions, events, and the like. 
"She always had a LACKLUSTER expression on her face, as if she weren't interested in anything." 
"It was a LACKLUSTER performance--nothing very good about it, nothing very bad about it." 
Many people think LACKLUSTER means _terrible_. LACKLUSTER, however, is not that strong. It merely means _dull_, _uninteresting_, _lacking brilliance_.

CONVULSION.deftext:
a fit, disturbance, upheaval 
To CONVULSE is to shake violently. 
"California was CONVULSED by an earthquake." 
CONVULSION is the noun from CONVULSE. A CONVULSION is a violent shaking or disturbance, particularly the uncontrolled irregular movements of the muscles during a fit. In this case the word is usually used in the plural. 
"The child went into CONVULSIONS after she swallowed the poison." 
A CONVULSION can also be any kind of disturbance or upheaval. 
"Constant social CONVULSIONS kept the nation in a state of chaos for years." 
The most popular wrong answers on the Pretest are _illness_ and _urge_. A CONVULSION can be caused by an _illness_, but its meaning is much more specific. The choice of _urge_ is probably due in most cases to a confusion between CONVULSION and _compulsion_, which is a strong _urge_. 
Other forms of the word: CONVULSE, v. CONVULSIVE, adj.

PLAUSIBLE.deftext:
likely, apparently reasonable 
Something that is PLAUSIBLE has the appearance of being true. A PLAUSIBLE argument sounds true and makes sense, even if in fact it is not true. 
"He gave the teacher a PLAUSIBLE reason about why he hadn't done his homework." 
"Her excuse sounded PLAUSIBLE at the time, but later on we found out she had been lying." 
The opposite of PLAUSIBLE is IMPLAUSIBLE, which mean _unlikely_, _improbable_. 
"The account of his adventures sounded IMPLAUSIBLE, but in fact that was exactly what had happened." 
Other forms of the word: PLAUSIBILITY, n.

WHIMSICAL.deftext:
playful, fanciful, fantastic 
WHIMSICAL is an adjective from WHIMSY. See _-ic_ under Suffixes. WHIMSY is odd or fanciful humor, or the product of such humor. 
"He is full of WHIMSY; he always has such fanciful ideas." 
Someone or something that is WHIMSICAL is full of such odd notions or behavior. 
"Although usually very serious, he could sometimes be very strange and WHIMSICAL." 
"Her WHIMSICAL behavior bewildered everyone. She was always doing the oddest things at the most unexpected times." 
"He told the children a WHIMSICAL story about how elves paint the grass green." 
Other forms of the word: WHIM, n. WHIMSY, n.

ABORIGINE.deftext:
a native, original inhabitant 
Note the pronunciation. The _e_ is sounded. 
You can see the word _origin_ in ABORIGINE. ABORIGINE comes from the Latin phrase _ab origine_, which means "from the beginning." An ABORIGINE is one of the native people of a region or country. ABORIGINES have lived in a particular region "from the beginning." They were the very first people to come into the region from somewhere else and settle there. 
"The colonists arriving from across the sea found the ABORIGINES friendly and willing to share their land." 
"The invading tribe conquered the ABORIGINES and made them leave their native land." 
The word ABORIGINES is also used for the original flowers and animals in a particular region. 
Other forms of the word: ABORIGINAL, adj.

CEREBRAL.deftext:
mental, intellectual 
The CEREBRUM is a part of the brain. The basic meaning of CEREBRAL is "of the CEREBRUM or the brain." See _-al_ under Suffixes. CEREBRAL _palsy_ is a disability caused by damage to the brain. When used about people or their activities, CEREBRAL means _intellectual_, as opposed to _emotional_. A CEREBRAL person mainly uses his reasoning and critical powers, and not his intuitions or instincts. 
"He is a CEREBRAL writer; his stories aren't exciting, but they give a lot of food for thought."

INCITE.deftext:
to stir up, spur on, urge on, arouse 
To INCITE is to stir up, to urge somebody to do something. Usually the word suggests that something bad is being stirred up. 
"Her fiery speeches INCITED them to riot." 
"His tales of gold hidden inside INCITED the crowd to break into the building and steal everything they could find." 
"The assassination of the prince INCITED violence between the two warring parties." 
The noun from INCITE is INCITEMENT, something that stirs people up. 
"The umpire's one bad call was enough of an INCITEMENT for the crowd to boo him for the rest of the game." 
Other forms of the word: INCITEMENT, n.

COSMOPOLITAN.deftext:
worldwide, universal, worldly 
COSMOPOLITAN comes from two Greek words. The _cosmo_ part of the word means _world_ or _universe_; it is also found in the words COSMOS and COSMONAUT. The _polit_ part means _citizen_; it also appears in _politics_ and _police_. COSMOPOLITAN is used about people or things that are at home all over the world. It is especially applied to people who are free from local prejudices or interests, who have a broad, sophisticated outlook. 
"Jim has a COSMOPOLITAN background; he lived in six different countries before he was twelve." 
"He believed that statesmen should have a COSMOPOLITAN point of view when trying to solve world problems."

DERIVATION.deftext:
source, origin 
To DERIVE means to _take_ or _obtain_, especially from a source. 
"We DERIVE great pleasure from watching television." 
"The name of this town is DERIVED from an Indian word." 
The DERIVATION of something is its source or origin. 
"What is the DERIVATION of the custom of collecting candy on Halloween?" 
DERIVATION is used especially about the development of a word from earlier words. 
"Many English words are of Latin DERIVATION." 
"The teacher explained the DERIVATION of the word amateur." 
Other forms of the word: DERIVATIVE, adj. DERIVE, v.

FRACAS.deftext:
a disturbance, uproar, noisy quarrel, fight, brawl 
A FRACAS is a noisy disturbance, an uproar. The word is generally used about people fighting or disagreeing with one another. 
"A FRACAS erupted among some spectators who had been drinking." 
"Two policemen were injured trying to end the FRACAS." 
"A nice party suddenly became a FRACAS when everyone started arguing about politics." 
A FRACAS is smaller and less serious than a _riot_, but larger and usually more violent than a _quarrel_.

MANIFOLD.deftext:
numerous, various, diverse 
The suffix _-fold_ means "multiplied by." To increase something a _hundredfold_ means to increase it a hundred times. The _mani-_ part of MANIFOLD is the word _many_. So MANIFOLD basically means "multiplied by many." The word is used about things or actions that are numerous and varied, or that have many different features or uses. 
"As head of the organization he has MANIFOLD responsibilities." 
"One of the machine’s MANIFOLD advantages is that it is easy to fix." 
The most commonly chosen incorrect answer in the Pretest is _obvious_. This is probably due to a confusion of MANIFOLD with _manifest_. _Manifest_ means "clear to the senses,", _evident_, _obvious_.

QUIRK.deftext:
a peculiarity of behavior 
The basic meaning of QUIRK is "a sudden twist or curve." It is still used this way in the phrase "a QUIRK of fate," which is a sudden twist or change of fate. Usually today the word means "twists" of behavior--that is, personal peculiarities or mannerisms. 
"If you ignore some of the QUIRKS of his personality, he's really a very nice fellow." 
"She has this odd QUIRK of always wanting to be the last one to arrive at a party."

NONPAREIL.deftext:
unequaled, having no equal, the best, peerless 
NONPAREIL is a French word used in English; it means _not equaled_. See _non-_ under Prefixes. Anything which is NONPAREIL cannot be topped. It is the best. 
"She has a marvelous, NONPAREIL beauty." 
"He was a NONPAREIL boxer." 
Sometimes NONPAREIL comes after the word it modifies. 
"He was a boxer NONPAREIL." NONPAREIL is also a noun, meaning "a person or thing that has no equal." 
"She was a NONPAREIL as a pianist. I've never heard anyone better."

PANG.deftext:
a sharp pain 
A PANG is a sudden, brief, sharp pain. 
"The starving man felt PANGS of hunger." 
The word is more commonly used about mental pain than physical pain. It is used about a piercing feeling of sorrow, longing, or a similar strong emotion. 
"He suffered PANGS of conscience after he stole the bicycle." 
"Jane felt a PANG of envy when she saw how popular Mary was." 
"With a PANG of regret they looked back for the last time at their old house." 
"She was eighteen when she first felt the PANGS of love."

SWOON.deftext:
to faint; to become enraptured 
SWOON means to _faint_ or _lose consciousness_. Often SWOON is used about people in a state of sudden excitement or rapture. 
"The young girls SWOONED when they saw their favorite singer come into the room." 
"He felt faint and nearly SWOONED at the sight of so much beauty." 
SWOON is also a noun meaning a _faint_ or a _fainting fit_. 
"She started to regain consciousness and come out of the SWOON."

HALLOWED.deftext:
holy, sacred, blessed 
To HALLOW something is to make it holy or to treat it as sacred. HALLOWED is the adjective from HALLOW and means _sacred_, _holy_. 
"We walked solemnly past the HALLOWED ground of the graveyard." 
"No one was allowed to touch the HALLOWED objects that had once belonged to the saint." 
November 1 is the Feast of All Saints, which used to be _All_ HALLOW. So October 31 is HALLOWEEN, which is short for _All_ HALLOW _Evening_. 
The most popular mistake on the pretest for HALLOWED is _haunted_, due to the confusion caused by HALLOWEEN and the tales of ghosts and demons we associate with it. 
Other forms of the word: HALLOW, v.

IMPLORE.deftext:
beg, beseech, request earnestly 
To IMPLORE someone is to call upon him urgently for help, mercy, or the like. 
"I IMPLORE you not to let us down when we need you the most." 
"We IMPLORED the teacher not to give us any homework." 
To IMPLORE something is to ask for it urgently. 
"We IMPLORED his forgiveness." 
"He IMPLORED her to help him, and finally she agreed." 
IMPLORE means almost exactly the same as _beg_, except that usually IMPLORE is a stronger word. 
"I asked him to come. Then I begged him. Finally I IMPLORED him to come."

PROCURE.deftext:
to get, obtain 
PROCURE means to _get_, especially as the result of effort and planning. 
"We managed to PROCURE our supplies before they ran out." 
"She was unable to PROCURE the necessary funds." 
"He had to go to a hardware store ten miles away to PROCURE the special tool he wanted." 
_Protect_ and _save_ are often mistakenly chosen as the meaning of PROCURE, perhaps because of confusion with the word _secure_.

ALLOT.deftext:
to assign, distribute by lot 
_Lots_ are objects like straws or pebbles used to decide something by chance. To _draw lots_, for example, is to choose pieces of paper or the like to decide who will do something, who wins something, etc. To ALLOT something is to distribute it or divide it up as if by lot. Usually the word doesn't suggest the actual drawing of lots. 
"He took whatever he was ALLOTTED and didn't complain, even if it was much less than everyone else received." 
"The ALLOTTED time for his speech had ended, but he refused to stop talking." 
The noun from ALLOT is ALLOTMENT, which means "a share or portion." 
"His ALLOTMENT was only nine dollars." 
_Permit_ is often thought to be the meaning of ALLOT, probably because ALLOT looks so much like _allow_. 
Other forms of the word: ALLOTMENT, n.

BLASPHEME.deftext:
to curse, speak irreverently 
BLASPHEME comes from a Greek word meaning to _speak evil_. In English BLASPHEME also means to _speak evil_, especially to talk in an irreverent or abusive way about God or something sacred. 
"The church leaders said he had BLASPHEMED the name of God by his criticisms of religion." 
BLASPHEMY is an act of irreverence toward something sacred. 
"The priest said the youths committed BLASPHEMY by writing swear words on the church doors." 
Other forms of the word: BLASPHEMOUS, adj. BLASPHEMY, n.

MELEE.deftext:
a confused struggle, free-for-all, brawl 
Note the pronunciation. MELEE is a French word, and has kept its French pronunciation. 
A MELEE is a confused struggle involving a crowd of people. 
"A MELEE broke out among the fans at the football game." 
"The police had to use tear gas to break up the MELEE." 
MELEE is also used about a confused or disorganized crowd in general, without the suggestion of fighting. 
"He elbowed his way through the MELEE of people trying to finish their Christmas shopping."

PLACATE.deftext:
to soothe, pacify, appease, mollify 
To PLACATE means to _soothe_ someone who is hostile or offended, usually by making concessions. 
"In order to PLACATE his teacher Bob did extra homework that weekend." 
"We tried to PLACATE Jane, but everything we did seemed to make her even angrier." 
"He PLACATED the store owner by agreeing to return everything he had stolen."

VEHEMENT.deftext:
intense, strong, passionate, emphatic 
VEHEMENT means _intense_, _passionate_, _earnest_. 
"The lawyer had some VEHEMENT objections to the judge's rulings." 
VEHEMENT is often used about the way people talk or act. 
"His VEHEMENT tone left no doubt that he was quite upset about the matter." 
"Jim VEHEMENTLY denied having taken the money." 
Other forms of the word: VEHEMENCE, n.

STEADFAST.deftext:
faithful, loyal, firm, unswerving 
The _stead_ part of STEADFAST comes from an old English word meaning _place_. A _homestead_, for example, is a place where you have your home. The _fast_ part does not mean _quick_ or _speedy_, but comes from another use of the word which means _firmly fixed_. You can see this use of _fast_ in the word _fasten_. So something which is STEADFAST is firmly fixed in place. Usually today STEADFAST is used about people, and means "firmly fixed in one's beliefs or loyalties," _faithful_, _resolute_. 
"He was a STEADFAST friend. He would always help you when you needed it most." 
"She STEADFASTLY maintained her innocence despite all the proof that she was guilty."

ALOOF.deftext:
distant, indifferent, remote 
ALOOF is used about people who like to keep the feelings and opinions of others at a distance. ALOOF people stand apart and don't become involved in the affairs of others. Often the word suggests that this happens because these people feel superior to the rest of us. 
"Mary always remained ALOOF from the other children, as if she thought their games were too silly for her." 
"He was very warm and friendly with his family, but at work he seemed quite ALOOF."

The leaf drifted VEHEMENTLY down to the ground.
The STEADFAST horse raced around the track in record time.
The rich boy kept ALOOF from all the other children at school.

BENEVOLENT.deftext:
kindly, good, humane 
The _bene_ part of BENEVOLENT means _good_ or _well_; it is also used in words like _benefit_ and _benefactor_. The _vol_ part of the word means _wish_. A BENEVOLENT person wishes other people well; he wants to make other people happy, and therefore is generous and kindly. See _-ant_ under Suffixes. 
"The BENEVOLENT woman worked as a volunteer in a hospital and gave thousands of dollars to charity." 
BENEVOLENT is also used about people's actions and attitudes, and about places that exist to do good works. 
"The teacher took a BENEVOLENT attitude toward her students, and tried to help them in every way she could." 
"The BENEVOLENT institution provides toys for poor children at Christmastime." 
Other forms of the word: BENEVOLENCE, n.

GUISE.deftext:
outward appearance, aspect, semblance 
The GUISE of something is its outward appearance, the way it looks. The word may often suggest that this appearance is false or misleading. 
"The prince walked through the city streets in the GUISE of a poor beggar." 
"Under the GUISE of friendship he offered to help them find the money; he really wanted to keep it all for himself." 
To DISGUISE something is to change its appearance or GUISE. 
"The thief got into the house by DISGUISING himself as a mailman." 
Other forms of the word: DISGUISE, n., v.

CONTRIVE.deftext:
to invent, design, concoct; to manage or devise a way To CONTRIVE something or to CONTRIVE to do it is to find a way of doing it. 
The word suggests the use of cleverness in achieving something that may be rather difficult. 
"She CONTRIVED a device that would open locked doors without a key." 
"He CONTRIVED to get both the enemies into one room together to discuss their differences." 
"The author CONTRIVED a happy ending for his novel." 
The adjective CONTRIVED is used about things that show too clearly that they are planned and artificial. 
"His remarks were clever but rather CONTRIVED, as if he had rehearsed them all beforehand." 
Other forms of the word: CONTRIVANCE, n. CONTRIVED, adj.

DEPICT.deftext:
to describe, represent 
DEPICT is related to the word _picture_. To DEPICT something is to draw it or describe it, to make a picture of it. Something can be DEPICTED in a real picture, in words, on stage, etc. 
"The painting DEPICTS the king as a young man." 
"He is DEPICTED in the novel as a mean, vicious scoundrel." 
"The actress tried to DEPICT the emotions of the character she was playing." 
"The writer DEPICTED the horrors of war." 
Other forms of the word: DEPICTION, n.

JAUNDICED.deftext:
yellowish; hostile, prejudiced, jealous 
JAUNDICE is a disease which turns the skin yellow. JAUNDICED skin or a JAUNDICED appearance, therefore, looks as if it has been affected by JAUNDICE: it is yellow or yellowish. 
JAUNDICE can affect the vision, and people with JAUNDICE sometimes see things as being yellow. JAUNDICED has therefore come to be used about people who see things as being worse than they are, because of envy, suspicion, prejudice, and so on. 
"He looked with a somewhat JAUNDICED eye on their plan to hitchhike across the country"--that is, he wasn't very much in favor of it, and thought it would turn out badly. 
Other forms of the word: JAUNDICE, n.

PENSIVE.deftext:
thoughtful, deep in thought 
Someone who is PENSIVE is deep in thought. Often PENSIVE suggests a dreamy kind of thoughtfulness, where a person isn't reasoning a problem through but is simply in a reflective, almost sad mood. 
"She sat there for a long time with a PENSIVE, far-away look on her face." 
"Jim became rather PENSIVE whenever he remembered those sad incidents in his life."

SQUANDER.deftext:
to waste, spend carelessly, throw away foolishly 
To SQUANDER something is to waste it, to use it up extravagantly and carelessly. The word is used especially about time and money. People who are careful about saving money do not SQUANDER it. 
"He SQUANDERED his pay on gambling." 
"When the day of the test came, she was sorry that she had SQUANDERED all of her time watching television." 
"She SQUANDERED her life on foolish pleasures."

ULTERIOR.deftext:
hidden, not obvious, unseen 
ULTERIOR comes from a Latin word that means _lying beyond_, _lying further off_. In English the word usually has the sense "being beyond what is seen or admitted" and suggests that something is purposely being kept concealed. The word is generally used about purposes, motives, and the like. 
"Not a shadow of his ULTERIOR purpose was visible in his actions." 
"He pretended to be friendly toward the others, but I knew that he had an ULTERIOR motive for it." 
"The child was so open and innocent that one could not suspect him of having ULTERIOR thoughts."

AMASS.deftext:
to gather, accumulate, pile up 
To AMASS is to pile up into a mass, to heap up or accumulate. The word is usually, although not always, used about something that is valuable. 
"He AMASSED huge amounts of gold." 
"I AMASSED a great deal of knowledge during high school." 
"Jim AMASSED thousands of bottle caps over the years." 
"Jane AMASSED a fortune by buying and selling stocks."

KINDRED.deftext:
related, similar 
Your KIN are your family, your relatives. 
"Her KIN stood by her when everyone else had deserted her." 
KINDRED, as a noun, is another word for KIN. 
"All his KINDRED came to visit him when he was ill." 
As an adjective, KINDRED means "having a common source," _related_. 
"English and German are KINDRED languages." 
KINDRED also means "having much in common," _similar_. 
"They were KINDRED spirits; they had the same opinions about almost everything."

ORDINANCE.deftext:
an order, law, rule 
ORDINANCE is related to the word order. An ORDINANCE is a law or rule, usually one issued by a city or town. 
"The city council passed an ORDINANCE forbidding smoking in public places." 
"There is a local ORDINANCE that makes littering punishable by a fifty dollar fine."

KNOLL.deftext:
a small hill, mound 
A KNOLL is a small hill, usually with a rounded shape. 
"The land was flat except for a few gentle KNOLLS in the distance." 
"It took us only a minute or two to climb to the top of the KNOLL."

ORIFICE.deftext:
an opening, mouth, aperture 
ORIFICE comes from the Latin word for _mouth_, also the source of the word _oral_. ORIFICE is used for any outer opening or mouth of something. 
"The ORIFICE of the tube had become blocked up with dirt." 
"The creature had a small ORIFICE through which it took in food and air."

QUASH.deftext:
to put an end to, beat down, crush 
QUASH is related to the word _squash_, and both have about the same meaning: to _beat down_, _crush_. QUASH, however, is used more about rebellions, chances, hopes, rumors, and the like, than about physical objects. 
"The army QUASHED the rebellion easily." 
"The airplane strike QUASHED our hopes of getting home for Christmas."

SLOVENLY.deftext:
untidy, sloppy, careless 
A SLOVEN is a person who always dresses, acts, or works in a messy, slipshod manner. SLOVENLY is the adjective from SLOVEN. (It is an adjective even though it ends in _-ly_.) A person is SLOVENLY if he is sloppy or careless about his appearance or work. 
"She is so SLOVENLY. She looks as though she sleeps in her clothes." 
"Jim's SLOVENLY appearance makes a very bad impression on people." 
SLOVENLY is also used about people's activities and products. 
"It was a SLOVENLY report, full of mistakes and erasures." 
"The supervisor criticized the mechanic's SLOVENLY workmanship." 
Other forms of the word: SLOVEN, n.

FACADE.deftext:
the front (of a building); a false appearance 
Note the pronunciation. The _c_ is soft. 
The FACADE of a building is its front, the part which faces the street and which most people see. 
"The bomb damaged the FACADE of the hotel, but the people inside were unharmed." 
Sometimes, to make a small building appear to be bigger than it actually is, the FACADE is extended above the building's top floor. Such a FACADE is called a _false front_. 
"The FACADE of the building is two stories high, but the building has only one floor." 
From this meaning FACADE has come to be used for any outward appearance, especially one which is false or misleading. 
"She looked calm, but this was just a FACADE; she was really very angry." 
"Their apparent wealth was all a FACADE; in fact, they could barely afford the clothes they wore." 
Usage: FACADE is also sometimes spelled _façade_.

ADULTERATE.deftext:
to make impure, corrupt, pollute 
ADULTERATE has nothing to do with the word _adult_. To ADULTERATE something is to make it less pure, usually by adding a substance that is of poorer quality. The word is used especially about foods and drugs. 
"He claimed the hamburger had been ADULTERATED by the addition of harmful chemicals." 
The word is also sometimes used in a general sense. 
"Her happiness was ADULTERATED by the continuing suspicion that it was all about to end." 
The word UNADULTERATED means _pure_ or _sheer_. 
"Everything he says is UNADULTERATED nonsense"--that is, it is complete and total nonsense. 
Other forms of the word: ADULTERATION, n. UNADULTERATED, adj.

CLEAVE.deftext:
to split, tear, cut apart 
To CLEAVE something is to split it apart, especially with a cutting blow--for example, from an ax. 
"He could CLEAVE the log with one mighty swing of his ax." 
"The force of the explosion CLEAVED the boulder in two." 
CLEAVE can also he used about the thing being cut. 
"This kind of wood CLEAVES easily." 
In a slightly different sense, the word can also mean "to make way for, by (or as if by) cutting." 
"They CLEAVED a path through the jungle." 
A CLEAVER is a heavy instrument used by butchers to cut up animals. 
Other forms of the word: CLEAVER, n. 
Usage: CLEAVE is a rather formal word, used more in print than in speech. The past tense of CLEAVE can be CLEAVED, CLOVE, or CLEFT. Interestingly, CLEAVE has a second meaning that is almost the opposite of the meaning given above; it means "to cling to or be firmly attached to," as in "The wet uniforms cleaved to their bodies."

ENUMERATE.deftext:
to count, list, name one by one 
ENUMERATE comes from the same Latin source as _number_, _numeral_, _numerous_, and other words having to do with numbers and counting. ENUMERATE can mean simply to _count_, but it usually has the sense of "counting off" or listing items one after another. 
"He began to ENUMERATE the reasons why we shouldn't go." 
"We ENUMERATED the qualities we thought the new employee should have." 
In most cases it is better to use the simpler words _count_ and _list_, unless the sense is specifically to count off one after another. 
Other forms of the word: ENUMERATION, n.

AFFIX.deftext:
to attach, fasten, stick firmly in place 
To AFFIX something is to attach it to something else. 
"You must AFFIX a stamp to that letter or else the post office won't deliver it." 
The AFFIXING doesn't have to be a physical act. 
"The teacher AFFIXED a severe penalty to cheating on the test." 
"He AFFIXED great importance to the professor's remarks." 
AFFIX is often used about adding your signature to something. 
"He had to AFFIX his signature to the bottom of the document to make it legal." 
AFFIX comes from the same source as the word _fix_. AFFIX has nothing to do with _fix_ in the sense of _repair_. Fix, though, can mean "to put firmly in place" as in the phrase "to _fix_ in your memory." The two words in this sense have close to the same meaning.

PRECIPICE.deftext:
a steep cliff 
A PRECIPICE is a very steep cliff, one that has almost a vertical face to it. 
"Everyone was afraid to go very near the edge of the PRECIPICE." 
"The mountain climbers decided it would be almost impossible to reach the top of the PRECIPICE." 
Sometimes PRECIPICE is used in a general sense for the brink of any kind of disaster. 
"The nation now stands on the PRECIPICE of a severe economic depression." 
In the Pretest, many people choose _valley_ as the meaning of PRECIPICE. A PRECIPICE is a cliff which might lead down into a _valley_, but it is not the _valley_ itself.

AGAPE.deftext:
wide open, gaping; in a state of wonder. 
AGAPE is related to the words _gap_ and _gape_. The word means _wide open_. It is usually used about a person's mouth, which might be open because of wonder, surprise, a yawn, or the like. 
"His mouth was AGAPE when he saw who had walked in the door." 
"The crowd was AGAPE at the astounding feats of the acrobats." 
Many people choose _horrified_ as the synonym for AGAPE. A person's mouth may be AGAPE because of horror, but the word means _wide open_, not _horrified_. 
Usage: AGAPE always comes after the noun it modifies.

SUBMISSIVE.deftext:
tame, yielding, compliant, docile 
SUBMISSIVE is an adjective from SUBMIT. See _-ive_ under Suffixes. One meaning of SUBMIT is "to yield to someone else's authority, to surrender." 
"When the police arrived, the burglar submitted without a struggle." 
Someone who is SUBMISSIVE is inclined to SUBMIT, to yield to power or authority. 
"They were very SUBMISSIVE children. They would obey anyone who gave them an order." 
"Why are you so SUBMISSIVE? You shouldn't do everything he tells you to do." 
Other forms of the word: SUBMIT, v. SUBMISSION, n.

ANTAGONISM.deftext:
hostility, opposition, enmity 
ANTAGONISM is active opposition, between people or groups, for example, who are unfriendly or in conflict. The word usually suggests a basic dislike which can easily be stirred up into actual fighting. 
"The natives felt an ANTAGONISM toward the tourists who swarmed into their town every summer." 
"Jim's mother tried to end the ANTAGONISM between his brother and him." 
Many people pick _suffering_ as the meaning of ANTAGONISM, probably because they see the word _agony_ in ANTAGONISM. Actually, both words come from a Greek word meaning _struggle_, but they have developed very different meanings. 
Other forms of the word: ANTAGONIST, n. ANTAGONISTIC, adj. ANTAGONIZE, v.

APPENDAGE.deftext:
an attachment, accessory, addition 
The _pend_ part of APPENDAGE comes from the Latin word for _hang_, also the source of English words like _pendant_ and _pendulum_. An APPENDAGE is something that is attached or added on to something else so that it is part of it. See _ad-_ under Prefixes. In biology, arms, legs, tails, and fins are appendages. In general use, however, the word usually suggests that this added-on part is not very important or essential. 
"The shed was merely a small APPENDAGE of the large house." 
"The fancy knobs and dials on the machine were useless APPENDAGES; they were just there to make it look impressive." 
To APPEND something is to add or attach it to something else. 
"A bibliography was APPENDED to the book before they published the second edition."

DOMICILE.deftext:
a home, dwelling place, residence 
A DOMICILE is a home or dwelling place. The word is especially used to mean "a person's legal residence"--that is, where he can be considered to live for voting or tax purposes. 
"The judge ruled that her legal DOMICILE was in New York State." 
"He decided to establish his DOMICILE in Cleveland"--in other words, he decided to live there. 
DOMICILE is also a verb. To DOMICILE is to reside or dwell. 
"They DOMICILED in the south of the country during the winter months."

GUFFAW.deftext:
a noisy burst of laughter 
A GUFFAW is a loud, coarse laugh. Originally the word was probably just an imitation of the sound of this kind of laugh. 
"The comedian's act certainly didn't produce any GUFFAWS in the audience; all we could hear were a few scattered giggles." 
GUFFAW can also be used as a verb. 
"The audience GUFFAWED when the villain slipped on a banana peel." 
The most commonly chosen wrong answer on the Pretest is _bitter cry_, which is opposite in meaning to GUFFAW.

STRATA.deftext:
layers, levels 
STRATA is the plural of STRATUM. A STRATUM is an even layer of something. STRATA are several of these layers, one on top of the other. The word is most often used about layers of rocks, but it is also used about other things like social classes. 
"Geologists can study the history of the Earth by examining the STRATA of rock formations." 
"Various STRATA of society were represented on the committee."

BUFFOON.deftext:
a clown, jester 
A BUFFOON is a _clown_, someone who says or does foolish things to entertain people. 
"The BUFFOON stood on his head and barked like a dog to amuse the king." 
In general, BUFFOON is an insulting term for any extremely stupid or foolish person. 
"He called his opponent a BUFFOON and said he was too stupid to be president." 
BUFFOONERY is clown-like behavior. 
"Stop all this BUFFOONERY and act your age." 
The most commonly chosen wrong answer is _monkey_, probably because of confusion with _baboon_, which is a kind of _monkey_. 
Other forms of the word: BUFFOONERY, n.

ADVOCATE.deftext:
to recommend, support 
To ADVOCATE something is to speak or write publicly in favor of it. 
"She ADVOCATES a shorter school day and longer vacations for students." 
"Everyone at the meeting seemed to ADVOCATE a different way of solving the problem." 
"No one on the committee ADVOCATED doing away with taxes entirely." 
ADVOCATE is also a noun. An ADVOCATE is someone who defends or pleads for a cause or a person. 
"The plan's strongest ADVOCATES are the ones who will gain the most from it." 
Other forms of the word: ADVOCACY, n.

DESPOT.deftext:
a tyrant, absolute ruler 
DESPOT was originally an honorary title applied to the emperor of Byzantium. From this the word came to be used about any ruler with absolute and unlimited powers. Nowadays DESPOT usually suggests a ruler who uses these powers unjustly or cruelly. 
"The DESPOT imprisoned everyone who criticized him." 
"The owner of the company used to be fairly reasonable, but lately he has become a real DESPOT, demanding complete obedience in everything." 
The actions or character of a DESPOT are called DESPOTIC. 
"The king's DESPOTIC treatment of the peasants caused them to revolt." 
Other forms of the word: DESPOTIC, adj. DESPOTISM, n.

GENTEEL.deftext:
polite, well bred, refined 
GENTEEL is related to the word _gentle_, but the words have taken on very different meanings and should not be confused. GENTEEL means "having the style or characteristics of the upper class," _refined_, _well bred_. 
"The two very GENTEEL ladies were shocked by the filthiness of the house." 
GENTEEL is usually used with a slightly sarcastic sense, as if the politeness and good breeding were put on or out of place. The word is often found in the phrase "GENTEEL poverty," which refers to people who try to maintain the style of the upper classes, even though they are too poor to do this very well.

INSUBORDINATE.deftext:
disobedient, rebellious 
See _in-2_ and _sub-_ under Prefixes and _ate2_ under Suffixes. A person who is a SUBORDINATE is in a lower position than someone else, and he has to obey the people who are above him. 
"He is a poor boss. He treats his SUBORDINATES as if they didn't have any feelings." 
Someone who is INSUBORDINATE is unwilling to be a SUBORDINATE. He is disobedient and rebels against authority. 
"Some of my employees were so INSUBORDINATE that I had to fire them." 
"The private was accused of being INSUBORDINATE to an officer." 
Other forms of the word: INSUBORDINATION, n.

GIRTH.deftext:
circumference, size 
GIRTH comes from an old word for _belt_. A GIRTH is the belt that goes around a horse to keep the saddle in place. GIRTH has come to mean the measurement around something, especially the measurement around a person's body. 
"For a short person he has a very large GIRTH; it is difficult to find a pair of pants that fit him." 
"They tried to estimate the GIRTH of the tree trunk before they actually measured it." 
"His huge GIRTH made it difficult for him to get in and out of cars."

INTERJECTION.deftext:
an exclamation 
See _inter-_ under Prefixes. The _ject_ part of the word means _throw_. It is also found in words like _project_ and _reject_. To INTERJECT means to _throw_ in a comment or remark in the middle of what someone else is saying. 
"'But that's not true!' he INTERJECTED in the middle of the professor's speech." 
An INTERJECTION is a word or phrase suddenly shouted out in excitement. _Wow!_ _Stop!_ _Oh, no!_ _Go ahead!_ are all examples of INTERJECTIONS. 
Other forms of the word: INTERJECT, v.

REBUKE.deftext:
to scold, criticize, censure 
To REBUKE someone is to criticize him sharply, to speak severely to him. 
"The teacher REBUKED him for speaking out of turn." 
"She was REBUKED by her parents for staying out late." 
REBUKE is also a noun, meaning "a strong expression of disapproval," a _reproof_. 
"She received a strong REBUKE for not making her bed."

LISTLESS.deftext:
spiritless, indifferent 
See _-less_ under Suffixes. The _list_ part of the word comes from an old word meaning _desire_. Someone who is LISTLESS lacks desire; he is too bored or tired to do anything. The word is used about people's moods, appearance, and actions. 
"The girl has been in a LISTLESS mood all day. She won't do anything; she just lies on her bed and stares at the ceiling." 
"He greeted them with a LISTLESS handshake which showed he wasn't very interested in meeting them." 
"Pete made a LISTLESS attempt to do his homework, then gave up and went back to watching television."

PARAPHERNALIA.deftext:
equipment, apparatus, furnishings 
PARAPHERNALIA is the equipment used for a particular kind of job or a particular purpose. 
"A baseball player's PARAPHERNALIA includes bat, ball, glove, and uniform." 
"The fishermen stowed all their PARAPHERNALIA under the seats of the boat." 
"When he first entered the laboratory, he didn't know what half of the PARAPHERNALIA was."

REPERCUSSION.deftext:
an effect, result, consequence 
See _re-_ under Prefixes. The _percuss_ part of the word comes from a Latin word meaning to _strike_. _Percussion_ instruments are musical instruments, like drums and cymbals, which make sounds by being struck. A REPERCUSSION is a striking or beating back, such as when a body hits another body that resists it. The word is usually used in a general sense about the effects, often indirect or widespread, of a particular action. 
"There will certainly be REPERCUSSIONS if we decide to fire him." 
"No one knew what the REPERCUSSIONS of this decision would be." 
"The REPERCUSSIONS of his speech were felt far and wide."

VIABLE.deftext:
capable of living; workable 
See _-able_ under Suffixes. The _vi_ part of VIABLE comes from the French word _vie_, which means _life_. Something which is VIABLE is able to live or exist, is capable of surviving. The word is used about unborn babies who have developed enough to be capable of living outside the womb. In a sense that has developed from this, VIABLE means "capable of being done," _workable_. 
"His plan was clever but not particularly VIABLE. It would cost a lot and require a great deal of work." 
"After some initial problems, their agreement proved to be quite VIABLE." 
__Changeable is the most commonly chosen wrong answer in the Pretest, probably because VIABLE is confused with the word _variable_.

BAUBLE.deftext:
a trinket, plaything, ornament 
A BAUBLE is a bright, pretty object that has little or no usefulness. It may or may not be expensive. 
"He bought some little BAUBLE for the child to keep her occupied during the long trip." 
"She bought several shiny BAUBLES just because she liked the look of them." 
"He said the jewel was just a BAUBLE that he hoped she liked."

ATTAlN.deftext:
to reach, achieve, gain 
To ATTAIN something is to gain it or reach it. The word generally suggests that some effort was needed, or that what was gained was valuable. 
"You must study if you wish to ATTAIN knowledge." 
"She ATTAINED her present high position by hard work and talent." 
"It will be impossible to ATTAIN our goal without more help." 
_Hold_ is the most common mistake as the meaning of ATTAIN. This is probably due to confusion between ATTAIN and _retain_. To _retain_ something is to hold on to it. 
"Once he had ATTAINED power he did his best to _retain_ it." 
Other forms of the word: ATTAINMENT, n.

BERATE.deftext:
to scold, rebuke, criticize sharply 
To BERATE someone is to scold him sharply and angrily, often for an extended period of time. 
"The teacher BERATED Tim for constantly being late." 
"There is no need to BERATE the child. She already said she was sorry for her mistake." 
"My mother is constantly BERATING me because my room is so messy."

CONSENSUS.deftext:
a general agreement, collective opinion 
See _con-_ under Prefixes. The _sens_ part of the word means to _feel_ or _think_. It comes from the same Latin word as _sense_ and _sentiment_. A CONSENSUS is a _feeling together_, a general opinion shared by a number of people. 
"It was the CONSENSUS of the group that much more work would have to be done." 
"The class was unable to reach a CONSENSUS about the best place to have the Christmas party." 
"The CONSENSUS of the coaches was that he was the best player in the league."

IMPASSIVE.deftext:
emotionless, unmoved, indifferent 
Someone who is IMPASSIVE shows no signs of feeling or interest. He has no emotions, at least none that anyone can see. 
"She remained IMPASSIVE while they told her of her mother's accident." 
"He stared IMPASSIVELY at them as they threatened to torture him." 
"Ken came back to the room with an IMPASSIVE look on his face. No one could tell whether he had passed or failed the test."

He had most of the usual PARAPHERNALIA for cleaning the house, but he couldn't find the vacuum cleaner.
They had a long REPERCUSSION about the best way to raise money.
Despite predictions of disaster, the new nation proved to be quite VIABLE, and actually flourished.
He bought her a ring, bracelet, and some other BAUBLES for her birthday.
He ATTAINED this house for five years before selling it.
Frank's mother BERATED him for lying to her.
Most people thought it was a great movie, but Jane's CONSENSUS was that it was terrible.
They tried to make him laugh, but he continued to gaze IMPASSIVELY at them.

SAGE.deftext:
wise, judicious 
SAGE means _wise_. The word is especially applied to a person who is wise through long experience. 
"The old judge was noted for his SAGE opinions." 
"The SAGE teacher gave him good advice about how to solve the problem." 
SAGE is also a noun, meaning "a profoundly wise man." 
"The ancient SAGES knew a great deal about human nature."

INDULGE.deftext:
to humor, pamper, spoil, give way to, gratify 
To INDULGE someone is to satisfy his wishes and demands, even if he has little right to make them. 
"Grandmother INDULGES those children too much. She lets them do whatever they want." 
To INDULGE yourself is to give in to your own desires or feelings. 
"After the long journey she INDULGED herself by taking a hot bath and eating at the best restaurant in town." 
To INDULGE _in_ something is to give in to your desire for it. 
"They INDULGED in ice cream and cake after dinner." 
"He INDULGES in the luxury of a cruise every year." 
Other forms of the word: INDULGENCE, n. INDULGENT, adj.

RECTIFY.deftext:
to correct, make right 
The _rect_ part of both RECTIFY and _correct_ comes from a Latin word meaning _right_. Both words mean "to make or put right." See _-fy_ under Suffixes. 
"He tried to RECTIFY his mistake but only made it worse." 
"She demanded that they RECTIFY their bad habits." 
"If we cannot RECTIFY this problem soon we will have to end the entire project." 
The most commonly chosen wrong answer in the Pretest is _change_. You can _change_ something and make it wrong; to RECTIFY is only to make something right.

INSURRECTION.deftext:
an uprising, rebellion, revolt 
INSURRECTION comes from a Latin word which means to _rise up_ and which is also the source of the words _surge_ and _insurgent_. An INSURRECTION is a rising up of people in resistance to authority or the government. It is usually less well organized than a rebellion or a revolution. 
"The leaders of the INSURRECTION claimed that half the population supported their cause." 
"The army crushed the INSURRECTION with little difficulty."

REPREHENSIBLE.deftext:
blameworthy, deserving censure 
See _-able_ under Suffixes. REPREHEND is a rather uncommon word that means to _criticize_, to _reprove_. Someone or something that is REPREHENSIBLE deserves to be criticized. 
"I think your actions were REPREHENSIBLE. You ought to be severely punished." 
"His opinions are fine, but the way he forces everyone to agree with them is REPREHENSIBLE." 
"Everyone thought the company's decision to make the work day longer was REPREHENSIBLE." 
_Puzzling_ is the most commonly chosen wrong answer on the Pretest, perhaps because REPREHENSIBLE looks like _incomprehensible_, which means _not understandable_.

SOLACE.deftext:
comfort, consolation, relief 
SOLACE means _comfort_ or _relief_ from sorrow or pain. 
"He looked for SOLACE from his troubles." 
SOLACE is also the thing that brings comfort. 
"Her children were a SOLACE to her in her old age." 
"The money her husband left her in his will was little SOLACE to her after his death." 
"Nothing seemed to comfort him until he found some SOLACE in music."

MEMOIRS.deftext:
a life story, autobiography, recollections 
Note the pronunciation. MEMOIRS is a French word, and keeps the French pronunciation. 
The word MEMOIRS is related to the word _memory_. MEMOIRS are a person's life story, usually telling about events and people that he has personal knowledge of. 
"The general wrote his MEMOIRS about his experiences during the war." 
"Everyone wanted to know what the movie star would say about these people in his MEMOIRS." 
MEMOIRS is sometimes used in the singular. 
"She wrote a MEMOIR of her early days in the fashion industry." 
_Short reminders_ is the most popular wrong answer on the Pretest, due to confusion with the word _memo_.

RECOMPENSE.deftext:
a reward, payment, compensation 
A RECOMPENSE is a return or payment made for work, loss, or injury. The word suggests making up for something, an attempt to do justice or to make amends. 
"He thought the RECOMPENSE they offered was not adequate for the loss of his home." 
"The company gave her a Christmas bonus as partial RECOMPENSE for all the extra work she had done that year." 
"We must make some RECOMPENSE for causing him to miss his plane flight." 
RECOMPENSE is also a verb. 
"The insurance company RECOMPENSED him for the theft of the camera."

TlNGE.deftext:
a trace, slight coloring, slight mixture 
TINGE may be used either as a noun or as a verb. A TINGE is a _trace_ or _slight mixture_ of something. The word is especially used about a slight trace of a color found in something, but it can also be used about traces of emotions in the face or voice. 
"There is a TINGE of green in the sky." 
"There was a TINGE of sadness in his expression as he walked out the door." 
When used as a verb, TINGE means to _color_ or _affect slightly_. 
"The white tile floor was TINGED with yellow after only a few months." 
"Her voice was TINGED with regret as she declined the invitation." 
"The air was TINGED with the pleasant aroma of freshly baked bread."

VANQUISH.deftext:
to defeat, overcome, conquer 
VANQUISH means to _defeat_ or _conquer_, but it is stronger than these words. VANQUISH usually suggests an important, complete defeat or conquest of an enemy. 
"The victorious general had VANQUISHED the enemy." 
One can VANQUISH other things besides enemies. 
"The disease was totally VANQUISHED after they developed the new medicine." 
"He was able to VANQUISH his fears about flying and board the plane."

BREVITY.deftext:
shortness, briefness 
BREVITY is shortness of time. BREVITY is the noun usually used in association with the adjective _brief_. 
"The program was very brief; we were surprised by its BREVITY." 
"The poet mourned the BREVITY of human life." 
"The BREVITY of this book was more than made up for by its wisdom and humor." 
Many people choose _value_ as the meaning of BREVITY, perhaps because BREVITY is usually considered to be a virtue.

VENDETTA.deftext:
a blood feud 
VENDETTA is the Italian word for _vengeance_. A VENDETTA is a feud between two families that starts when one family murders someone in the other family. Then the second family murders someone in the first family for revenge. And so it goes on and on, sometimes for generations. The most famous American VENDETTA was between the Hatfields and the McCoys. 
"Romeo and Juliet were forbidden to marry because there was a VENDETTA between their families." 
"After years of VENDETTA, the two families decided on a truce before they were all wiped out." 
Sometimes the word is used in a general sense for any feud that goes on for a long time. 
"He had a personal VENDETTA with the company that had sold him the broken typewriter."

DELETE.deftext:
to erase, take out, cancel, eliminate 
To DELETE something is to take it out, to erase or omit it. The word is usually used about written or printed matter. 
"They decided to DELETE this section of the chapter before the book was printed." 
"The teacher DELETED Bill's name from the list of those going to the museum." 
"I was asked to DELETE that sentence from my speech." 
Many people confuse DELETE with _shorten_. To DELETE something is to strike it out entirely, not just to shorten it. 
Other forms of the word: DELETION, n.

MIRTH.deftext:
merriment, laughter, gladness 
MIRTH is gladness or happiness accompanied by laughter and fun. 
"Everyone was full of MIRTH at the Christmas party." 
"They could barely hide their MIRTH as he slipped on a banana peel." 
Other forms of the word: MIRTHFUL, adj. MIRTHLESS, adj.

RABBLE.deftext:
a mob, disorderly crowd 
A RABBLE is a crowd or mob of people who act stupidly or unthinkingly. The word is always used in an insulting sense. 
"He ignored the RABBLE who tried to block his way." 
"The RABBLE in the stadium shouted insults at the referee." 
A RABBLE-_rouser_ is a person who tries to stir up a mob, usually by making speeches. 
"Several RABBLE-rousers urged the mob to take the law into its own hands."
