We worked hard on the INSURRECTION of the newspaper; we wanted to make sure everything was perfect.
You are old enough now to be REPREHENSIBLE for your own actions.
It took a great deal of SOLACE to understand what the professor meant.
In her MEMOIRS she wrote about all the famous people she had met.
The salesman ran up considerable RECOMPENSES while he was on the road.
There was a TINGE of anger in his voice when he told them to stop talking.
The senator VANQUISHED all his opponents in the election.
I was impressed by the BREVITY with which he could present a complicated argument.
They waged a political VENDETTA against the senators who had voted against the bill.
He said that the third clause had to be DELETED before he would sign the contract.
The actress's silly faces caused some MIRTH in the audience.
The angry old man said that those teenagers were ignorant RABBLE and should all be locked up.

SMUG.deftext:
self-satisfied, pleased with oneself, complacent 
A SMUG person is quite pleased with himself. SMUG people firmly believe they are right or superior, and take delight in being better than others. SMUGNESS is not a very admirable quality. 
"Alice felt quite SMUG after she had beaten her brother at tennis." 
"SMUG in his belief that he knew the subject, he didn't bother studying for the test." 
"She gave her friends a SMUG smile as she walked up to the stage to receive her award." 
Other forms of the word: SMUGNESS, n.

VINDICTIVE.deftext:
vengeful, unforgiving 
VINDICTIVE means "showing a desire for revenge." A VINDICTIVE person by nature wants to get even with anyone who wrongs him. 
"She's a VINDICTIVE person. If she thinks you've said something bad about her, she'll spend weeks trying to get back at you." 
"My father was stern, but he wasn't VINDICTIVE." 
"He made some VINDICTIVE remarks about his old enemy." 
"We don't want to be VINDICTIVE; we just want to get back the money he took from us."

BEDEVIL.deftext:
to torment, harass, annoy, plague 
_Be-_ is a prefix which forms verbs out of nouns. To BEDEVIL someone is to treat him _devilishly_, usually by constantly annoying or worrying him. 
"The mosquitoes BEDEVILED us when we camped by the lake." 
"This project has been BEDEVILED by problems since the beginning." 
"She was BEDEVILED by minor illnesses all year." 
In the Pretest, the most commonly chosen incorrect answer is _astound_, perhaps due to a confusion of BEDEVIL with _bedazzle_, which means to _impress forcefully_.

NEGLIGIBLE.deftext:
unimportant, small, not worthy of attention 
See _-able_ under Suffixes. Anything that is NEGLIGIBLE is able to be neglected without worrying about it, usually because it is so unimportant or tiny. 
"The medicine had a NEGLIGIBLE effect. She was no better after taking it than before." 
"His attempts to help us were NEGLIGIBLE. I don't think he tried very hard." 
"You get a NEGLIGIBLE saving by buying the large economy size. It's just not worth it."

EDIFYING.deftext:
uplifting, enlightening, instructive 
EDIFYING and its related verb EDIFY are from the same Latin root as _edifice_, which means "a large and impressive building." To EDIFY originally meant simply to _build_. Now it is only used in the sense of "to build up one's mind or morals." 
An "EDIFYING experience" is one which improves you spiritually or intellectually. It is not necessarily an enjoyable experience, although it may be. 
"The teacher said it would be an EDIFYING experience for us to go to the museum." 
"The minister delivered a very EDIFYING sermon." 
Other forms of the word: EDIFY, v. EDIFICATION, n.

MALEFACTOR.deftext:
a criminal, evildoer 
MALEFACTOR comes from Latin words meaning "to do evil." A MALEFACTOR is a criminal, or anyone who does evil to another. 
"Some unknown MALEFACTOR broke several windows in the school last night." 
"The MALEFACTORS must not be allowed to get away with their crime." 
The opposite of MALEFACTOR is _benefactor_, someone who does good to other people.

MUSE.deftext:
to think, meditate, ponder, reflect 
To MUSE _on_ or _over_ something is to think silently about it. The word usually suggests a dreamy or wondering attitude rather than serious thought. 
"He MUSED on the shortness of human life." 
"She MUSED over the good times they used to have." 
"Sally MUSED about the beauty of nature."

REPROACH.deftext:
to blame, criticize, rebuke 
To REPROACH someone is to find fault with him, especially in a tone that suggests sorrow or the need for sorrow. The idea is often that of shaming a person into being better. 
"Jim's mother REPROACHED him for forgetting her birthday." 
"The teacher REPROACHED the students for not studying harder." 
REPROACH is also a noun, meaning _blame_ or _censure_. A person whose reputation is "above REPROACH" has never done anything he might be blamed for. 
"His criminal activities brought REPROACH on his entire family." 
Other forms of the word: REPROACHFUL, adj.

ENVOY.deftext:
a messenger, agent, deputy, representative 
ENVOY is from a French word meaning to _send_. An ENVOY is a person sent somewhere as a representative of a government, business, group of people, etc. 
"We sent him as our ENVOY to meet with our opponents." 
"The ENVOY came to beg us to forgive his king." 
In diplomacy, ENVOY is a specific rank of diplomat, second in importance after an ambassador. 
Note the different pronunciations. Sometimes words from foreign languages keep their foreign pronunciation for a long time in English. ENVOY seems to be in the process of changing from the French pronunciation _on'-voy_ to the English _en'-voy_.

FISSURE.deftext:
a narrow crack or opening 
A FISSURE is a long, narrow crack, usually rather deep, and usually made by splitting or breaking. 
"The earthquake caused many FISSURES to appear on the sides of the mountain." 
In a broader sense, a FISSURE is a division or disagreement which threatens to break up a group of people. 
"A FISSURE developed in the party between those who supported the war and those who opposed it." 
"His stand on unemployment opened up many FISSURES in his previously solid support."

COALESCE.deftext:
to unite, join together 
To COALESCE is to come or grow together into one body or group. COALESCE often suggests a slow or natural process of growing together. 
"Over time the land between them was built up and the two islands finally COALESCED." 
"Several small parties managed to COALESCE into one important political organization."

DELUGE.deftext:
a flood, downpour 
A DELUGE is a great flood, usually caused by a tremendous downpour of rain. A DELUGE can also be anything that overwhelms like a flood. 
"When the movie star was sick, the hospital received a DELUGE of mail." 
"There was a DELUGE of criticism when the popular teacher was fired." 
DELUGE is also a verb meaning to _flood_. 
"When the dam broke, towns along the river were DELUGED." 
"They DELUGED the company with requests for more information." 
"He was DELUGED with job offers after he graduated from school." 
_Battle_ is the most commonly chosen wrong answer, possibly because DELUGE sometimes has a sense of violence and destructiveness.

FARCICAL.deftext:
absurd, laughable, ridiculous 
A FARCE is a comedy, usually one filled with silly characters and unbelievable situations. 
"We expected a serious drama, but it turned out to be a light-hearted FARCE." 
A FARCE is also any situation or event that is like such a comedy. 
"Everything seemed to go wrong; the entire picnic was a complete FARCE." 
FARCICAL is the adjective from FARCE. See _-ic_ under Suffixes. Something that is FARCICAL is like a FARCE, so silly and extreme that it is funny. 
"His attempts to explain why he was late were almost FARCICAL." 
"It was a FARCICAL game. The players seemed to make up the rules as they went along." 
Other forms of the word: FARCE, n.

SURMISE.deftext:
to guess, suspect, suppose, think 
To SURMISE means "to believe without strong evidence," to _guess_ or _suppose_. 
"He SURMISED that there would be a surprise party for him." 
"The detective SURMISED that the burglars had entered the house through an open window." 
SURMISE is also a noun, which means a _guess_. 
"Her SURMISE proved to be correct."

ASSENT.deftext:
to agree, consent, concur 
To ASSENT to something is to agree to it. ASSENT often does not suggest strong support but a weaker kind of "going along." 
"My father ASSENTED when I asked him if I could go to the movies." 
"I cannot ASSENT to the idea that all men are basically evil." 
"Everyone ASSENTED to the proposal that we have a party." 
ASSENT is also a noun, meaning _agreement_. 
"The teacher gave her ASSENT to our suggestion that we have a class picnic." 
Usage: ASSENT is often followed by _to_.

With a SMUG air of superiority he showed them how to put the puzzle together.
Our VINDICTIVE neighbors built a large fence just to block our view.
Doubts about his decision continued to BEDEVIL him long after it had been made.
Although they worked hard at cleaning the house, the results were NEGLIGIBLE; it was just about as dirty as before.
She only bought top-quality food to EDIFY her family.
He had a secret MALEFACTOR who sent him the money to finish college.
The comedian MUSED us with his jokes.
The car REPROACHED us at seventy miles an hour.
The president sent his personal ENVOY to talk with the king.
The debate over whether to hire him caused a FISSURE in the organization.
The six streams meet and COALESCE into a river.
They DELUGED him with prizes after he won the contest.
His explanation of how electricity works was so obviously wrong it was almost FARCICAL.
From the way Bill was acting, Mary SURMISED that he was unhappy in his new job.
She ASSENTED the fact that he made more money than she did for doing the same job.

EMPHATIC.deftext:
forceful, insistent, strongly expressive, striking 
EMPHASIS is the stress or force used to show that something is important. 
"The coach laid great EMPHASIS on speed." 
EMPHATIC is the adjective from EMPHASIS. See _-ic_ under Suffixes. EMPHATIC means _forceful_, _insistent_. 
"The mayor issued an EMPHATIC denial to the rumor that he was seriously ill." 
"Jim's tone was EMPHATIC when he said he would never let Bill drive his car again." 
"The teacher said EMPHATICALLY that there would be absolutely no talking during the test." 
Other forms of the word: EMPHASIS, n. EMPHASIZE, v.

INCEPTION.deftext:
beginning, start, commencement 
INCEPTION is a rather formal word for the _beginning_ or _start_ of something. The word is used especially about projects, organizations, practices, and the like. 
"Since the INCEPTION of the fund-raising drive we have received over ten thousand dollars." 
"I was present at the club's INCEPTION two years ago." 
"The plot of the novel changed greatly between the book's INCEPTION and its completion."

GINGERLY.deftext:
careful, cautious, wary 
GINGERLY means _careful_ or _cautious_. To do something in a GINGERLY manner is to do it with care, in order to avoid hurting yourself, making a noise, or breaking something. 
"They moved in a GINGERLY way across the beach, looking out for pieces of broken glass." 
GINGERLY is also an adverb. 
"He GINGERLY picked up the priceless vase and carried it across the room." 
"We walked GINGERLY through the minefield, afraid that any second we would be blown up."

IMPLEMENT.deftext:
a tool, instrument 
An IMPLEMENT is a _tool_, an object used in carrying out some kind of work. 
"She had a hoe, a rake, and other gardening IMPLEMENTS." 
"As part of the peace treaty they agreed to give up all their IMPLEMENTS of war." 
"Television can be used as an IMPLEMENT of education." 
IMPLEMENT is also a verb, meaning to _carry out_ or _put into effect_. 
"The workers were told to IMPLEMENT the president's new policy immediately." 
"It's easy to make a decision; it's more difficult to IMPLEMENT it." 
In the Pretest, the most popular wrong answer is _decoration_. This may be due to a confusion between IMPLEMENT and _ornament_, which is a _decoration_. 
Other forms of the word: IMPLEMENTATION, n.

PALPITATE.deftext:
to throb, beat rapidly, pulsate, quiver 
To PALPITATE is to beat rapidly and strongly, like the heart during exercise or strong emotion. 
"Her heart started to PALPITATE whenever she thought of the man she loved." 
"Running up the flight of stairs caused the man's heart to PALPITATE." 
Other forms of the word: PALPITATION, n.

INTREPID.deftext:
fearless, daring, brave 
See _in-2_ under Prefixes. The _trepid_ part of the word comes from a Latin word meaning _fear_, also the source of the English word _trepidation_. Someone who is INTREPID is _fearless_; he is daring and resolute when it comes to meeting danger. 
"The INTREPID explorers set off into the jungle, knowing they might never come out alive." 
Other forms of the word: INTREPIDITY, n.

MATRON.deftext:
a dignified married woman 
A MATRON is a married woman, especially a mature or dignified one with a high social position. 
"They were dignified old MATRONS who spent most of their time on the committees for various charities." 
MATRON is also used for the woman who is in charge of the housekeeping at a hospital, prison, or similar institution. 
Other forms of the word: MATRONLY, adj.

PALATABLE.deftext:
tasty, agreeable to the taste 
See _-able_ under Suffixes. The _palate_ is the roof of the mouth; it was once popularly thought to be where the sense of taste was located. Thus, something which is PALATABLE is agreeable to the _palate_ or the taste. The word is usually used about foods that are little more than acceptable to the palate, and not about foods which taste wonderful. 
"The dinner he cooked was at least PALATABLE, which is more than I expected." 
"This vegetable can be PALATABLE if it is cooked the right way." 
Sometimes PALATABLE is used in a general sense to mean _agreeable_, _acceptable_. 
"You may not find my criticisms very PALATABLE, but I'm still going to make them."

RETICENT.deftext:
silent, reserved, quiet 
Someone who is RETICENT is not inclined to say much, either out of caution or shyness. A RETICENT person keeps most things to himself, and only gives out information grudgingly. 
"She was RETICENT about what had happened that day. It was obvious she was hiding something." 
"He is usually RETICENT about all his accomplishments, but this time he told everyone." 
"Don't be RETICENT. Let us know how you feel." 
Other forms of the word: RETICENCE, n.

SORDID.deftext:
filthy, dirty 
Someone or something that is SORDID is filthy and disgusting. The word's basic meaning is _dirty_, but it always suggests uncleanness that is caused by evil or corruption. 
"It was difficult for children to grow up in these SORDID surroundings." 
"He had some SORDID habits which caused all decent people to avoid him." 
"The evil criminals carried out their SORDID plot to kidnap the child."

DISCREET.deftext:
tactful, cautious, careful 
A person who is DISCREET shows good judgment in what he says or does. He is very careful not to do anything which might harm his own interests or those of his friends. A DISCREET person can be trusted with a secret, or with a task that requires tact and diplomacy. 
"The DISCREET diplomat refused to criticize the leaders of the foreign country." 
"She thought it would be DISCREET to leave before the party got too wild." 
A "DISCREET silence" occurs when someone has decided that it's better not to say anything in a particular situation. 
Other forms of the word: DISCRETION, n. DISCRETIONARY, adj.

AGGRIEVED.deftext:
wronged, offended, troubled 
AGGRIEVED is related to the words _grief_ and _grieve_. To be AGGRIEVED is to be wronged or treated unjustly, so that you have cause for complaint. 
"He felt AGGRIEVED when the teacher punished him and not the rest of the students." 
"Bill had a permanently AGGRIEVED attitude; he thought that people were always treating him badly." 
The most commonly chosen wrong answer is _neglected_. Someone who is _neglected_ may have a right to feel AGGRIEVED, but the two words do not have the same meaning. 
Other forms of the word: AGGRIEVE, v.

EQUITY.deftext:
fairness, impartiality, justice 
EQUITY is related to the word _equal_. EQUITY is the quality of being fair, just, and impartial. 
"The EQUITY of his solution seemed to please everyone." 
"He thought that as a matter of EQUITY he should get a share." 
In English and American law, EQUITY is a particular system of rules and doctrines which is designed to correct or override other laws in cases where they appear to work unfairly. The adjective formed from EQUITY is EQUITABLE, which means _reasonable_, _just_. 
"It was hardly an EQUITABLE arrangement, since she paid for the car and he was the only one who could use it." 
Other forms of the word: EQUITABLE, adj.

LEGACY.deftext:
an inheritance, bequest 
A LEGACY is something, like land or money, left by will as a gift to someone else. 
"Her uncle left her a small LEGACY which helped pay for her college education." 
In a general sense, a LEGACY is anything received from the past or from our ancestors. 
"Their chief LEGACY to their children was a keen desire to help the unfortunate." 
"Those beautiful paintings are our LEGACY from the great artists of the past."

PLEBEIAN.deftext:
commonplace, undistinguished 
In ancient Rome there were two classes of people, the _plebs_, or common people, and the _patricians_, or nobles. The adjective PLEBEIAN means "of or relating to the plebs or common people." The word is used about people, things ,or activities that are considered crude or commonplace. 
"The nobleman didn't want his daughter to marry into such a PLEBEIAN family." 
"He considered himself too cultured to take part in so PLEBEIAN a sport as bowling." 
PLEBEIAN is also a noun. 
"I may only be a simple PLEBEIAN, but I have rights too."

questions.prompt: If a teacher puts EMPHASIS on neatness, does she care about it?
Has a project gotten very far at the time of its INCEPTION?
If someone had to carry a bomb, would he carry it GINGERLY?
Could a pen be considered an IMPLEMENT?
Can a baby be a MATRON?
Should a secret agent be DISCREET?
Is a person who feels AGGRIEVED likely to be angry at someone?
Should people be angry about an EQUITABLE decision?
Could a diamond ring be a LEGACY?
Would a duchess be a PLEBEIAN?
He struck the table EMPHATICALLY to show that he meant what he said.
The school held an INCEPTION so that everyone could meet the new principal.
They GINGERLY picked up the child and placed her in the ambulance.
They IMPLEMENTED the actor on his fine performance.
He PALPITATED the switch to make sure it worked.
He was so INTREPID that his hand started to shake as he opened the door.
His grandmother was a distinguished MATRON.
I expected a wonderful meal; instead I got some stale bread that was barely PALATABLE.
The RETICENT boy wouldn't tell his parents why he was afraid to go to school.
Everyone admired the SORDID way he treated his children.
When asked if she would run for reelection, the senator kept a DISCREET silence.
Her AGGRIEVED expression showed that she was feeling sorry for herself again.
We were amazed by the EQUITY of the arrangement, under which she got less pay for the same amount of work.
A continuing hostility between the two countries was the unfortunate LEGACY of the ancient war.
She felt that watching television was a PLEBEIAN activity, and refused to do it.

RECAPITULATE.deftext:
to sum up, summarize, restate briefly 
To RECAPITULATE means to _sum up_ an argument, a discussion, or the like, by going over the main points again. 
"At the end of the debate both sides briefly RECAPITULATED their positions." 
"She RECAPITULATED the reasons why she should be elected president." 
"I would like to RECAPITULATE what other writers have said about this novel." 
In the Pretest, many people choose _continue_ as the meaning of RECAPITULATE, but RECAPITULATE means to _summarize_, usually with a view towards ending a speech or an argument. 
Other forms of the word: RECAPITULATION, n.

EXODUS.deftext:
a mass departure, emigration 
The EXODUS was the departure of the Israelites from Egypt, described in the second book of the Bible. An EXODUS has come to mean any departure or going away of a large group of people, with or without the difficulties that the Israelites had in leaving Egypt. See _ex-_ under Prefixes. 
"The promise of better jobs in the growing cities caused a large EXODUS of workers from rural areas." 
The most popular wrong answer is _trip_, which is close to the meaning of EXODUS but not quite the same. One person could go by himself on a _trip_ to the store, but this would not be an EXODUS.

IMBIBE.deftext:
to drink, drink in, absorb 
IMBIBE comes from Latin words meaning "to drink in." See _in-1_ under Prefixes. The word means actual drinking and "drinking in" or absorbing ideas, knowledge, and the like. 
"He tried to IMBIBE all the knowledge the teacher could give him." 
When IMBIBE means actual drinking, it sometimes has a rather humorous tone. 
"The drunk said he only IMBIBED on national holidays."

HEW.deftext:
to cut, chop, carve 
To HEW something is to cut it. The word usually suggests a rough job of cutting, done with an ax, a sword, or the like. 
"He HEWED the trunk of the tree with one mighty blow of his ax." 
"This statue was HEWN out of solid rock." 
"They had to HEW a path for themselves through the thick jungle." 
"She HEWED the branches from the tree." 
Usage: The past participle of HEW is HEWN.

ILLUSTRIOUS.deftext:
famous, eminent, distinguished, celebrated 
ILLUSTRIOUS comes from a Latin word meaning to _brighten_, also the source of the word _luster_. People who are ILLUSTRIOUS are famous. They are brilliantly distinguished because of what they have done or because of their good qualities. 
"Our ILLUSTRIOUS ancestors made this nation as great as it is today." 
"This novel will make the ILLUSTRIOUS writer even more famous." 
"When the ILLUSTRIOUS judge retired, everyone honored him for his wisdom and mercy." 
_Hardworking_ is the most commonly chosen incorrect answer, probably because of confusion between ILLUSTRIOUS and _industrious_.

WANTON.deftext:
immoral, irresponsible, reckless, undisciplined 
The basic meaning of WANTON is "lacking discipline." The word is used in several ways using this idea. WANTON can mean "done unjustifiably," _malicious_. 
"The youths were charged with the WANTON attack on the old man." 
It can mean _extravagant_, _unchecked_. 
"Your WANTON spending is going to make us all poor." 
Or it can mean _immoral_, _unchaste_. 
"These WANTON people are a disgrace to the neighborhood." 
_Rare_ is the most commonly chosen wrong answer, perhaps because of the _want_ part of the word.

IMPART.deftext:
to make known, communicate, transmit, pass on 
To IMPART means to _communicate_, to _pass on_. The word is used in two different senses. The first is to _give_ or _pass on_ a quality or condition to something. 
"The new carpet IMPARTED a certain elegance to the dining room." 
"The general's signature at the bottom IMPARTED a great deal of authority to the orders." 
The second sense is simply to _tell_ or _make known_ something. 
"I want to IMPART some secret information to you." 
"The professor IMPARTED his knowledge to the students."

WILE.deftext:
a trick, ploy, ruse 
A WILE is a trick used to entrap someone or to lure him on. 
"The babysitter had to use all her WILES to get the children to go to bed." 
"He was not taken in by her WILES, and refused to go along with the scheme." 
"We used all our WILES, but we still couldn't get the teacher to postpone the test." 
WILY is the adjective from WILE. See _-y_ under Suffixes. WILY means _tricky_, _crafty_, _sly_. 
"The WILY old thief knew all the ways to steal people's money." 
Usage: WILE is usually used in the plural, WILES.

ESPOUSE.deftext:
to support, adopt, make one's own, come to believe in 
A _spouse_ is a marriage partner, a husband or wife. To ESPOUSE meant originally "to take as a spouse," to _wed_. The word is still sometimes used in this way, but it usually now has the sense "to attach yourself to a cause or a belief' as if you were married to it. 
"They eagerly ESPOUSED the doctrine of equal pay for equal work." 
"Everyone ESPOUSED the miners' cause." 
"He ESPOUSED a strange theory that turned out to be correct." 
ESPOUSE is a stronger word than _believe_ or _support_; it suggests more eagerness and completeness in your feelings. 
"Once he had ESPOUSED this new idea, no one could talk him out of it."

WROUGHT.deftext:
shaped, fashioned, formed 
WROUGHT is an old form of the past tense of _work_. WROUGHT as an adjective basically means _worked_. The word is usually applied to objects that have been carefully or elaborately fashioned, especially by hand. 
"He bought his wife a pair of beautifully WROUGHT earrings for her birthday." 
"The lovely hand-WROUGHT lampshade was quite expensive." 
When used of metals, WROUGHT means "beaten or hammered into shape with tools." 
"The candlesticks were WROUGHT of the finest silver." 
In a different sense WROUGHT is used in the phrase "WROUGHT up," which means _worked up_, _excited_. 
"My mother gets all WROUGHT up when I don't come home on time."

LAUDABLE.deftext:
praiseworthy, deserving praise, commendable 
See _-able_ under Suffixes. LAUD is a rare word meaning to _praise highly_. Something or someone that is LAUDABLE is able to be praised, is worthy of being praised. 
"Your desire to increase your vocabulary is LAUDABLE." 
"We thought his opinions were LAUDABLE, but we didn't like the way he insisted that everyone agree with him." 
_Understandable_ is the most commonly chosen wrong answer, perhaps because LAUDABLE sounds like _audible_, which means "able to be heard."

CULPABLE.deftext:
blameworthy 
See _-able_ under Suffixes. The _culp_ part of the word comes from a Latin word meaning _blame_, also the source of the word _culprit_. Someone or something that is CULPABLE is worthy of being blamed for something, deserves condemnation or punishment. 
"The judge said her parents were as CULPABLE for her crimes as she was." 
"You cannot consider him CULPABLE, since he was forced to do what he did." 
"His ignorance of the dangerous situation was CULPABLE, because it was his job to know about such things." 
The most commonly chosen incorrect answer is _effective_, probably because of a confusion between CULPABLE and _capable_. 
Other forms of the word: CULPABILITY, n.

PICAYUNE.deftext:
trivial, trifling, small, unworthy of notice 
A PICAYUNE was a small coin used in the Spanish colo- nies in America. When the Americans took over the word, it came to be used as an adjective which means _small_, _insignificant_, _practically worthless_. 
"She owes a PICAYUNE amount--not more than a dollar." 
"Several of the patients had PICAYUNE complaints about their treatment, but everyone was pleased in general." 
"He thought her criticisms were PICAYUNE; they were just about minor points that didn't make any difference."

SCATHING.deftext:
damaging, harmful, very severe 
SCATHING is an old English word which meant _harmful_, _damaging_, or _injurious_. SCATHING is now used chiefly about damaging or harmful words. 
"The reviewer gave a SCATHING criticism of the new play, saying that the author couldn't write and that the actors couldn't perform." 
"The boss's SCATHING reply to Ken's suggestion hurt him deeply." 
The related word UNSCATHED means _unharmed_, _undamaged_. 
"It was a miracle she walked away from the accident UNSCATHED." 
Other forms of the word: UNSCATHED, adj.

SUPERFICIAL.deftext:
shallow, trivial, insignificant 
SUPERFICIAL comes from the Latin word for _surface_. Something which is SUPERFICIAL is on the surface only; it doesn't go very deep. A SUPERFICIAL wound is a minor wound which just involves the surface of the skin. When applied to people and their actions, SUPERFICIAL means "concerned only with what is on the surface, with what is apparent and obvious." 
"It was a SUPERFICIAL report. It just gave the facts, not the reasons behind them." 
"The doctor gave him a quick, SUPERFICIAL examination and said he was all right." 
Other forms of the word: SUPERFICIALITY, n.

AFFINITY.deftext:
an attraction, natural liking, close connection 
An AFFINITY _for_ something is a strong liking for or attraction to it. 
"She found she had an AFFINITY for speaking in public." 
"They felt a strange AFFINITY for the deserted old house." 
An AFFINITY _with_ or _between_ things or people is a close resemblance or connection between them. 
"There is a strong AFFINITY between the two writers." 
"The English language has many AFFINITIES with German." 
AFFINITY has some very specific uses involving this basic idea of _attraction_ or _connection_. AFFINITY is relationship by marriage (as opposed to a relationship by blood). In chemistry, AFFINITY is the force by which atoms are held together in chemical compounds.

VISTA.deftext:
a view, prospect 
A VISTA is a _view_, especially one seen through or along a narrow passage or avenue. 
"We saw the beautiful VISTA of the distant mountains through the long rows of trees." 
"A VISTA of the huge mansion appeared to them at the end of the driveway." 
A VISTA can also be a mental view extending over long periods of time or many matters. 
"Einstein's theories opened many new VISTAS for research in physics."

ASPIRE.deftext:
to long, yearn, be ambitious 
To ASPIRE _to_ or _after_ something is to be filled with ambition to reach it or accomplish it. You usually ASPIRE to something grand or important. 
"Jane ASPIRED to the presidency." 
"She ASPIRED to be the best singer of her time." 
"Tom only ASPIRED after knowledge; nothing else mattered to him." 
ASPIRATION is the noun from ASPIRE and means _ambition_, _goal_. 
"His one ASPIRATION is to be a professional baseball player." 
Other forms of the word: ASPIRATION, n.

ASSIMILATE.deftext:
to absorb, take in 
To ASSIMILATE something is to take it in so that it becomes a part of you. The word can be used about food. 
"The body can ASSIMILATE some foods more easily than others." 
Or it can be used in a wider sense of ideas or knowledge. 
"Johnny found it difficult to ASSIMILATE all the material the teacher presented to the class." 
The word is also used about races and cultural groups. 
"It took many years before the immigrants were completely ASSIMILATED into American society." 
Other forms of the word: ASSIMILATION, n.

IMPETUS.deftext:
a moving force, impulse, stimulus 
IMPETUS is the force behind something, the energy with which it is moving. 
"He gave the tricycle a push, and this IMPETUS carried it all the way down the street." 
"The train didn't have enough IMPETUS to get to the top of the hill." 
IMPETUS is also used in a more general sense to mean any _driving force_ or _stimulus_. 
"The idea of getting rich quick was a strong IMPETUS behind the gold rush." 
"His enthusiasm was the real IMPETUS behind the project."

ARDENT.deftext:
burning, warm, passionate, enthusiastic 
ARDENT comes from a Latin word meaning to _burn_. ARDENT is now not often used about actual fire or heat, but means _on fire_ with desire, enthusiasm, or some other strong emotion. 
"He was an ARDENT supporter of free speech." 
"She felt an ARDENT desire to see her native land once more." 
"He spoke ARDENTLY of his love for his wife." 
The noun related to ARDENT is ARDOR, which means "warmth of emotion," _passion_, _zeal_. 
"His ARDOR for chess cooled when he started playing opponents who could beat him." 
Other forms of the word: ARDOR, n.

CONFOUND.deftext:
to confuse, mix up, puzzle, perplex 
CONFOUND comes from Latin words which mean to _pour together_. See _con-_ under Prefixes. To CONFOUND things is to mix them up so that one thing is confused with another. 
"The author's error is to CONFOUND the desire to do good with the good deed itself." 
To CONFOUND a person is to confuse him. CONFOUND in this sense is a rather strong word, and suggests such total puzzlement that it is difficult for a person to act. 
"The sudden disappearance of the jewels CONFOUNDED everyone." 
"They were CONFOUNDED by his stubborn refusal to go along." 
In the Pretest, many people choose _anger_ as the meaning of CONFOUND, probably because CONFOUND is used in a mild oath, "CONFOUND it." In this sense, CONFOUND means _damn_. It is an expression of anger, but it doesn't mean to make someone angry.

REVEL.deftext:
to make merry 
To REVEL is to make merry, to be festive. 
"They REVELED for days when they heard the war was over." 
To REVEL _in_ something is take great delight in it. 
"He seemed to REVEL in making people feel uncomfortable." 
"They REVELED in their freedom when school was over." 
REVEL is also a noun meaning _merrymaking_, _noisy festivities_. 
"It was quite a REVEL. The fun lasted until dawn." 
"There were REVELS every night on the millionaire's yacht." 
Other forms of the word: REVELRY, n.

BESTIAL.deftext:
beast-like, brutal, savage 
BESTIAL is an adjective from _beast_. See _-al_ under Suffixes. The word means "of or like a beast" and usually emphasizes the cruelty and savagery of a wild animal. 
"The BESTIAL soldiers killed the women and children in cold blood." 
"They should go to prison for life for their BESTIAL crimes." 
"His BESTIAL behavior when he has been drinking shocks everyone." 
The noun from BESTIAL is BESTIALITY, which is the quality of being a beast. 
"The BESTIALITY of these vicious criminals outraged the public." 
Other forms of the word: BESTIALITY, n.

ORDEAL.deftext:
a severe trial 
In ancient times, one way of deciding whether a person was guilty or innocent of a crime was to make the person undergo a severe or painful test like walking through fire. If the person survived this test, he was thought to be innocent of the crime. This test was known as an ORDEAL. 
Nowadays, ORDEAL is used for any severe test or trying experience. 
"Being lost in the desert without water was quite an ORDEAL." 
"For her, every math test was an ORDEAL." 
"It was a terrible ORDEAL for him to speak before a crowd."

AFFABLE.deftext:
pleasant, friendly, gracious 
See _-able_ under Suffixes. AFFABLE comes from Latin words meaning "able to speak to." An AFFABLE person is easy to talk to; he is friendly and polite to everyone. 
"The manager was unusually AFFABLE this morning; she laughed and joked with everyone on the staff." 
"Our boss is very AFFABLE; he even stops and says hello to the part-time clerks." 
_Competent_ is the most commonly chosen wrong answer. Perhaps the people who choose this are confused by the _-able_ part of AFFABLE and think the word means _capable_. 
Other forms of the word: AFFABILITY, n.

BLASÉ.deftext:
indifferent, world-weary 
BLASÉ is a French word, and keeps its French pronunciation. 
A BLASÉ person has experienced so many pleasures (or pretends that he has) that he has become bored with them. The things that excite or interest the average person leave him indifferent and unimpressed. 
"She was quite BLASÉ about winning the prize. You'd think it happened to her every day." 
"With a BLASÉ shrug of his shoulders he said it didn't matter to him whether he went on the trip or not." 
"He tried to act BLASÉ about being elected class president, but he couldn't hide his excitement." 
_Old-fashioned_ is the most commonly chosen incorrect answer, due to confusion with _passé_, which looks and sounds much like BLASÉ.

DEFILE.deftext:
to make dirty, corrupt, pollute 
To DEFILE something is to make it dirty or impure. DEFILE is a very strong word and suggests doing foul things to something that should be kept pure or sacred. 
"A madman DEFILED the statue by pouring garbage all over it." 
"He said his home was being DEFILED by the presence of such a vicious person, and he demanded that the man leave immediately."

BANAL.deftext:
commonplace, trite, worn-out 
Something that is BANAL lacks all freshness or originality. It is commonplace and uninteresting. 
"The speaker's BANAL remarks put everyone to sleep." 
"The plot of the novel was quite BANAL; I've read the same sort of thing a hundred times before." 
"All her ideas are BANAL; she hasn't had an original thought in her life." 
Many people choose _annoying_ as the meaning of BANAL. This may be due to confusion of BANAL with _bane_. A _bane_ is something that causes trouble or ruin. It is not related to the word BANAL. 
Other forms of the word: BANALITY, n.

EXONERATE.deftext:
to free from blame, clear, relieve 
EXONERATE comes from a Latin word meaning "to relieve of a burden." Occasionally EXONERATE is used to mean "to relieve of a task or duty." 
"No one can EXONERATE you from your duty to your parents." 
The word is usually used, though, in the sense "to free from the burden of blame." 
"The witness's testimony completely EXONERATED you." 
"They admitted the evidence seemed to EXONERATE him from any blame for the fire." 
EXONERATE gives the idea not only that the person is not guilty, but that he has been cleared so completely that all the burden of being suspected and accused falls away from him.
